The '''Penske PC-23''' was a highly successful [[Champ Car|CART]] racing car that competed in the [[1994 IndyCar season]] with [[Penske Racing]], and in [[1995 IndyCar season]] with [[HVM Racing|Bettenhausen Motorsports]]. It was designed by [[Nigel Bennett (car designer)|Nigel Bennett]],<ref name="PC232">{{cite web
|publisher=forix.autosport.com
|url=http://forix.autosport.com/8w/penske-mercedes-pc23-car.html
|title=Mercedosaurus Rex at Indianapolic Park, Part 10: Penske PC23 - a home for the engine
}}</ref> who based its design on the 1993 car, the [[Penske PC-22|PC-22]], which was a radical departure from the basic concept of the previous [[Penske Racing|Penske]] cars. The PC-23 was one of the most dominant open wheel race cars ever developed. It won both the 1994 CART season, and the [[1994 Indianapolis 500]] with [[Al Unser Jr.]], together with [[Emerson Fittipaldi]] and [[Paul Tracy]] scoring 12 wins out of 16 in total, collecting 10 pole positions and 28 podium finishes,<ref name="PC238">{{cite web
|publisher=race-database.com
|url=http://www.race-database.com/standings/standings.php?year=1994&series_id=4
|title=1994 CART PPG IndyCar World Series standings
}}</ref> in a season that saw Penske also take the Constructor's Cup, and the Manufacturer's Cup with the [[Ilmor]]-Mercedes-Benz engine. Nevertheless, the car is mostly known for the controversial [[overhead valve|pushrod]] [[Mercedes-Benz in motorsport|Mercedes-Benz 500I]] engine,<ref name="PC233">{{cite web
|publisher=forix.autosport.com
|url=http://forix.autosport.com/8w/penske-mercedes-pc23.html
|title=The Penske-Mercedes PC23-500I
}}</ref> designed and developed for the single race of Indianapolis, exploiting a loophole in different technical rules between the Indy 500 and CART sanctioning bodies at that time.<ref name="PC239">{{cite news
|publisher=[[The New York Times]]
|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1994/05/22/sports/auto-racing-penske-drives-through-loophole-and-into-indianapolis-front-row.html?pagewanted=1
|title=AUTO RACING; Penske Drives Through Loophole And Into Indianapolis Front Row
| first=Joseph
| last=Siano
| date=1994-05-22
}}</ref>

==Overview==
The PC-23 was a design evolution of its predecessor, the [[Penske PC-22|PC-22]],<ref name="PC232"/> which won the [[1993 Indianapolis 500]], 8 races over the entire season, and missing the [[1993 IndyCar season|1993 CART]] title by only 8 points.<ref name="PC234">{{cite web
|publisher=race-database.com
|url=http://www.race-database.com/standings/standings.php?year=1993&series_id=4
|title=1993 CART PPG IndyCar World Series standings
}}</ref> The only substantial difference of the new car from it were the smaller rear wings on the [[Oval track racing|short ovals]], mandatory by rule changes for the 1994 season, and Team Penske put in a lot of test efforts to minimize the effects of these changes. There were also some modifications on the transmission, but the new car was mostly an progression. Plans to fit the PC-23 with an [[active suspension]] system were canceled due to a ban by CART on such technology.<ref name="PC232"/> The car and the Ilmor engine were ready for testing by mid December 1993.

The Indy 500 version of the PC-23, showed a much higher engine cover, required because of the new engine. Other modifications included changes to the input gears of the [[gearbox]], to cope with the lower rpm and higher power and [[torque]] the pushrod engine provided. However, the two versions of the gearbox were of the same weight, thus causing no shift in the weight balance. The Mercedes-Benz 500I engine was slightly lighter than the Ilmor Indy V8, although because of its longer inlets the center of gravity of the entire engine was higher than that of the 500I, thus changing the overall balance of the car a bit.<ref name="PC232"/> The development and testing of the 500I engine, at that time called Ilmor 265E, took place in the utmost secrecy, because there was a possibility of the turbocharger boost level being changed, or the engine being banned by the Indy 500 sanctioning body.<ref name="PC232"/>

==Racing history==
{{See also|1994 IndyCar season|1994 Indianapolis 500|1995 IndyCar season}}
[[File:Fittipaldi indy.jpg|thumb|left|180px|[[Emerson Fittipaldi]] driving the PC-23 at the [[1994 Indianapolis 500]]]]
The PC23 debuted at [[1994 Australian FAI Indycar Grand Prix]], noted for the sensational debut win of [[Reynard Motorsport|Reynard]] chassis,<ref name="PC235">{{cite web
|publisher=grandprix.com
|url=http://www.grandprix.com/gpe/cref-gorric.html
|title=PEOPLE: RICK GORNE
}}</ref><ref name="PC2310">{{cite news
|publisher=[[The New York Times]]
|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1994/03/21/sports/andretti-and-dad-finish-1st-and-3d.html?pagewanted=1?pagewanted=1
|title=Andretti and Dad Finish 1st and 3d
| date=1994-03-21
}}</ref> qualifying 3rd with Fittipaldi, 5th with Al Unser, Jr. and 6th with Tracy. In the race, which was shortened by 10 laps due to darkness, Fittipaldi scored a 2nd place, while Unser and Tracy retired for electrical problems. At Phoenix, the first oval race of the season, the PC23 scored its first win, with Fittipaldi ahead of Al Unser, Jr. The season continued with six wins in a row, three for Unser: [[Grand Prix of Long Beach|Long Beach]], [[1994 Indianapolis 500|Indianapolis]] and [[ABC Supply Company A.J. Foyt 225|Milwaukee]], where Penske Racing scored a remarkable 1-2-3 win with Fittipaldi second and Tracy third, a win for Tracy at [[Detroit Indy Grand Prix|Detroit]], and two wins for Unser at [[Grand Prix of Portland|Portland]], another 1-2-3 sweep for Penske, and [[Grand Prix of Cleveland|Cleveland]]. In [[Honda Indy Toronto|Toronto]] however, Unser's engine blew, while Fittipaldi finished 3rd, and Tracy 5th, ending an astonishing streak of seven wins in a row. In [[Firestone Indy 400|Michigan]], the entire Penske pack retired, but for the next two races, [[Honda 200|Mid-Ohio]] and [[New Hampshire Motor Speedway|New Hampshire]], the Penskes scored two 1-2-3 wins in a row, with Unser as winner on both occasions. Unser won also in [[Molson Indy Vancouver|Vancouver]], completing his second row of 3 back to back wins of the season. The [[Champ Car Grand Prix of Road America|Road America]] was won by then rising star [[Jacques Villeneuve]], his first in CART racing, while Unser clinched the championship ahead of Fittipaldi. Two final events of the season, [[Firestone Indy 225|Nazareth]] and [[Monterey Grand Prix|Laguna Seca]] were won by [[Paul Tracy]]. Unser, Fittipaldi and Tracy, ended the season at first three places in season standings respectively.

In the [[1995 IndyCar season|1995]], not counting the brief and unfortunate attempt to qualify at Indy 500 with their year-old car,<ref name="PC236">{{cite web
|publisher=forix.autosport.com
|url=http://forix.autosport.com/8w/penske-mercedes-pc23-1995.html
|title=Part 18: The 1995 '500' - The Mercedosaurus bites its masters after all
}}</ref> Penske Racing was running with the new [[Penske PC-24|PC-24]], although with much less success. However, the [[HVM Racing|Bettenhausen Motorsports]] team used the PC-23 for almost the entire season, with the Indy 500 and Milwaukee as sole exceptions.<ref name="PC237">{{cite web
|publisher=forix.autosport.com
|url=http://forix.autosport.com/8w/penske-mercedes-pc23-1995-and-beyond.html
|title=Part 21: PC23's further active career after 1994
}}</ref> Bettenhausen driver [[Stefan Johansson]] scored points in eight races and finished a 13th place in the final standinds, with one third place as its best result. In [[1996 IndyCar season|1996]], the PC-23 had one final run, at the inaugural [[U.S. 500]] with [[Gary Bettenhausen]], who crashed out of the race in lap 89, while in the 21st place.<ref name="PC237"/>

===Mercedes-Benz 500I===
[[File:Indy 500.jpg|thumb|180px|The Penske PC-23 at the [[1994 Indianapolis 500]]]]
Much to the surprise of competitors, [[Sports journalism|media]], and fans, [[Penske Racing|Marlboro Team Penske]] arrived at the [[Indianapolis Motor Speedway]] with a brand new, secretly-built 209&nbsp;[[Cubic inch|cid]] [[Mercedes-Benz]] [[pushrod]] engine, which was capable of a reported 1000 [[horsepower]].<ref name="NYT 4-18">{{cite news 
| url=http://www.nytimes.com/1994/04/18/sports/auto-racing-penske-s-engine-has-opponents-singing-brickyard-blues.html
| title=AUTO RACING; Penske's Engine Has Opponents Singing Brickyard Blues
| publisher=The New York Times
| date=1994-04-18
| first=Joseph
| last=Siano
| accessdate=}}</ref> Despite reliability issues with the engine<ref name="NYT 4-18"/> and handling difficulties with the chassis,<ref name="NYT 5-22">{{cite news 
| url=http://www.nytimes.com/1994/05/22/sports/auto-racing-penske-drives-through-loophole-and-into-indianapolis-front-row.html
| title=AUTO RACING; Penske Drives Through Loophole And Into Indianapolis Front Row
| publisher=The New York Times
| date=1994-05-22
| first=Joseph
| last=Siano
| accessdate=}}</ref> the three-car Penske team ([[Al Unser, Jr.|Unser]], [[Emerson Fittipaldi]] and [[Paul Tracy]]) dominated most of the month, and nearly the entire race. This engine used a provision in the rules intended for stock block [[Cam-in-block|pushrod]] engines such as the [[V6 engine|V-6]] [[Buick]] engines that allowed an extra 650&nbsp;cm³ and 10&nbsp;[[Inch of mercury|inches]] (4.9&nbsp;[[Pound-force per square inch|psi]]/33.8&nbsp;[[Pascal (unit)|kPa]]) of boost. This extra power (at least 900 [[horsepower]], and rumored to be in excess of 1000 [[Horsepower|hp]], which was up a 150-200&nbsp;hp advantage over the conventional V-8s.<ref name="NYT 5-22"/>) allowed the Penskes to run significantly faster, giving them the pole and outside front row on the grid for the [[1994 Indianapolis 500|78th Indianapolis 500]]. [[Al Unser, Jr.]] and [[Emerson Fittipaldi]] dominated the race, eventually lapping the field with 16 laps to go in the 200 lap race when Emerson made contact with wall coming out of Turn 4, giving [[Al Unser, Jr.]] the lead and win. The only other driver who finished on the lead lap was rookie [[Jacques Villeneuve]].

In the summer and fall of 1993,<ref name="NYT 5-22"/> Ilmor and Penske engaged in a new engine program. Under complete secrecy,<ref name="NYT 5-22"/> a 209-cid purpose-built, pushrod engine was being developed.<ref name="NYT 4-18"/> [[Mercedes-Benz in motorsport|Mercedes]] took over the project, and dubbed the engine the ''Mercedes-Benz 500I''. The engine was designed to exploit a perceived "[[loophole]]" that existed in [[United States Auto Club|USAC]]'s rulebook since 1991.<ref name="NYT 5-22"/> While CART sanctioned the rest of the Indycar season, the Indianapolis 500 itself was conducted by USAC under slightly different rules.

In an effort to appeal to smaller engine-building companies, USAC had permitted "stock-block" pushrod engines (generally defined as single [[Overhead valve|non-OHC]] units fitted with two [[Poppet valve|valves]] per cylinder actuated by [[pushrod]] and [[rocker arm]]). The traditional "stock blocks," saw some limited use in the early 1980s, but became mainstream at Indy starting with the introduction of the [[Buick]] V-6 Indy engine. Initially, the stock blocks were required to have some production-based parts. However in 1991, USAC quietly lifted the requirement, and purpose-built pushrod engines were permitted to be designed for racing at the onset. Attempting to create an equivalency formula,<ref name="NYT 5-22"/> both pushrod engine formats were allowed increased [[Engine displacement|displacement]] (209.3&nbsp;[[Cubic inch|cid]] vs. 161.7),<ref name="NYT 4-18"/> and increased [[turbocharger]] boost (55&nbsp;[[Inch of mercury|inHG]] vs. 45&nbsp;inHG)<ref name="NYT 4-18"/>

Team Penske mated the engine with the in-house Penske chassis, the PC-23. It was introduced to the public in April, just days before opening day at Indy.

==Legacy==
The car in its Indy 500 version caused a considerable uproar at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway and in the [[Auto racing|racing world]] in general. Subsequently, the PC-23 was recognized as one of the triggers of the [[Champ Car|CART]]/[[Indy Racing League|IRL]] split,<ref name="PC231">{{cite web
|publisher=forix.autosport.com
|url=http://forix.autosport.com/8w/penske-mercedes-pc23-epilogue.html
|title=Mercedosaurus Rex at Indianapolic Park, Part 23: The loose ends that didn’t fit in anywhere else and the epilogue
}}</ref> which did huge damage to both series, to the following [[Champ Car]] ([[NASCAR]] exploited the situation to grow as the most popular racing series in US), and to today's again-unified [[IndyCar Series]], which don't have the international appeal, nor the technical advance that the CART enjoyed in early 1990s. The PC-23 influenced subsequent rule making at Indianapolis.

The first experimental vehicles were built in the 17th and 18th century, but it was not until after [[Richard Trevithick]] had developed the use of high-pressure steam, around 1800, that mobile steam engines became a practical proposition. The first half of the 19th century saw great progress in steam vehicle design, and by the 1850s it was viable to produce them on a commercial basis. The next sixty years saw continuing improvements in vehicle technology and manufacturing techniques and steam road vehicles were used for many applications. In the 20th century, the rapid development of [[internal combustion engine]] technology led to the demise of the steam engine as a source of propulsion of vehicles on a commercial basis prior to the [[Second World War]]. Since then there has been sporadic resurgences of interest in steam, particularly in the late 1960s in [[California]] to address air pollution issues and later in response to the [[1973 oil crisis]].

The manufacturers listed here were those active during the first period of [[steam car]] production, roughly 1860–1930, but mostly around 1900. From 1940 on steam cars listed here have tended to be either prototypes or experimental.

| Callihan || USA || 1884 || Designed by Edward Scott Callihan, it was a tricycle layout with a single spoked wheel in front and two at the rear. The driver sat behind the steam boiler on a seat from a reaper. It was steered it with levers. The top speed was 15&nbsp;mph. Only one was built.<ref>[http://www.southdakotamagazine.com/callihan Callihan's Infernal Machine], Roger Holtzmann, South Dakota Magazine, retrieved 14 July 2015</ref>
|-
| Catley and Ayres || England || 1863 || A small three-wheeled vehicle propelled by a horizontal twin cylinder engine which drove the rear axle by spur-gearing; only one rear wheel was driven, the other turning freely on the axle.

| Carhart || USA || 1871 || A steam buggy made by Dr J W Carhart of Rancine, Wisconsin.

|-
| Curtis || USA || 1867 ||In 1866 [[Francis Curtis]], [[Newburyport, Massachusetts]] invented a steam engine attached to a piece of fire fighting equipment. Curtis demonstrated it to [[Nehemiah Bean]] who went on to design the steam powered [[Amoskeag Locomotive Works|Amoskeag]] fire wagon. The following year Curits built a steam passenger carrriage for an unnamed client. The client didn't pay and Curits made the first repossession in American history. During the initial testing of the carriage a warrant was issued for Curtis' arrest. To escape the arresting officer Curtis made the first getaway by car in American history.<ref name=EarlyAmerican />
|-
| [[De Dion-Bouton et Trepardoux]] || France ||1883–1904 ||[[File:Marquise 1884.jpg|150px|right]] The company was renamed De Dion-Bouton, possibly as a result of Trepardoux resigning in 1894 over the use of petrol engines. The last steam powered cars were made in 1904. The company lasted until the 1950s.<ref name="Steam Cars, 1770-1970" /><ref name="Light Steam Power, De Dion Steam Tricycle" >{{cite journal
  |journal=[[Light Steam Power]]

}}</ref>

| [[Innocenzo Manzetti|Manzetti]] || Italy || 1864 || In 1864, Italian inventor [[Innocenzo Manzetti]] built a road-steamer.<ref name="manzetti">{{it}} [http://web.archive.org/web/20131212204632/http://www.innocenzomanzetti.it/leinvenzioni.html Innocenzo Manzetti - Le invenzioni]</ref> It had the boiler at the front and a single-cylinder engine.<ref name="manzetti"/>

| Mason || USA || 1885, 1897 || William B Mason of the Mason Regulator Company (now a subsidiary of [[Dresser Industries]] made his first steam carriage in 1885. He made a second car in July 1897. |-

  |title=De Dion-Bouton et Trépardoux steam quadricycle
  |url=http://www.steamcar.net/z-christies.html
  |publisher=[http://www.steamcar.net Steam Car Club of Great Britain]
}}</ref>
|-
| [[Ransom E. Olds|Olds]] || USA || 1886–1894 || Ransom Old's is reputed to have made his first steam powered car in 1886. He did make the first car exported from the United States in 1893. However, the ship sank and the car was never delivered.<ref>Chapter 2 Motoring Pioneers, Million Cars for Billion People, Gautam Sen, Leadstart Publishing Pvt Ltd, 2014, ISBN 938402774X, 9789384027742</ref>
|-
| [[Peugeot]] || France || 1889 || The first Peugeot automobile, a three-wheeled, steam-powered car designed by Léon Serpollet, was produced in 1889; only four examples were made.

| [[Rickett (car)|Rickett]] || England || 1860 ||Rickett made ploughs and steam engines. In 1858 he created a steam powered plought. This inspired the [[Marquess of Stafford]] to order a steam carriage. This vehicle had three wheels, the single wheel at the front, and a rear-mounted coal-fired boiler and two-cylinder engine. He made a second vehicle for the [[Earl of Caithness]] in 1860. These were potentially Englands first cars.

Roper]] drove around [[Boston]], Massachusetts on a steam carriage he invented in 1863.<ref name=LowellDaily1863>{{Citation |newspaper=[[Lowell Daily Citizen and News]] |location=[[Lowell, Massachusetts]] |date= 6 January 1863 |number= 2050 |quote=S. H. Roper, of Roxbury, has invented a steam wagon for common roads, which stops, turns corners, backs, 'keeps to the right as the law directs,' and does many other intelligent things under the hands of a skilful driver. }}</ref><ref name=NewHavenDaily1863>{{Citation |title=Miscellaneous Items; Mr Sylvester H Roper of Roxbury, Mass has invented a steam carriage… |newspaper=[[New Haven Daily Palladium]] |location= New Haven, Connecticut |date=  3 March 1863 |issue= 52 }}</ref><ref name=Pearson1965>{{Citation |title= Ford Museum Houses U.S. History |last=Pearson |first= Drew |newspaper= [[Daytona Beach Sunday News-Journal]] |pages= 8|url= http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QbItAAAAIBAJ&sjid=uMwEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3156,3215975 |accessdate=2011-02-06 |date=16 May 1965}}</ref><ref name=McCann1972>{{Citation |title=Museum Traces History of Wheels |first=Hugh |last= McCann |newspaper= [[The New York Times]] |date= 2 April 1972 |pages= IA27 }}</ref><ref>See also:
*  [http://ebooks.library.cornell.edu/cgi/t/text/pageviewer-idx?c=scia;cc=scia;rgn=full%20text;idno=scia1008-11;didno=scia1008-11;view=image;seq=169;node=scia1008-11%3A1;page=root;size=200 "An improved steam carriage,"] ''Scientific American'', new series, vol. 8, no. 11, page 165 (14 March 1863).
*  [http://ebooks.library.cornell.edu/cgi/t/text/pageviewer-idx?c=scia;cc=scia;rgn=full%20text;idno=scia1009-22;didno=scia1009-22;view=image;seq=345;node=scia1009-22%3A1;page=root;size=200 "New steam carriage,"] ''Scientific American'', new series, vol. 9, no 22, page 341 (28 November 1863).</ref> One of his 1863 carriages went to the [[The Henry Ford|Henry Ford Museum]], where, in 1972, it was the oldest car in the collection.<ref name="Pearson1965"/><ref name="McCann1972"/><ref name=Smithsonian3>{{Citation |url= http://americanhistory.si.edu/onthemove/collection/object_350.html |title = Sylvester Roper's steam carriage |publisher= [[Smithsonian Institution]] |last= Johnson |first= Paul F. |accessdate= 2011-02-06 }}</ref><ref name="Light Steam Power, Steam car makers" /><ref>http://www.earlyamericanautomobiles.com/americanautomobiles2.htm retrieved 13 July 2015</ref>

It was unveiled at the Stanstead Fall Fair that year.<ref name=bbc>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.com/autos/story/20150212-old-gold-the-henry-seth-taylor-steam-buggy |title=Old gold: The Henry Seth Taylor steam buggy |last1=Schultz |first1=Jonathan |last2= |first2= |date=February 12, 2015 |website=BBC Autos |publisher=BBC |access-date=February 23, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.virtualmuseum.ca/edu/ViewLoitDa.do;jsessionid=B5086890A2F909D2AC1506313FF3759E?method=preview&lang=EN&id=19537 |title=Henry Seth Taylor Steam Buggy, 1867
 |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=2011 |website=Virtual Museum |publisher=Canada Science and Technology Museum.
 |access-date=February 23, 2015}}</ref>

|-
| Whitney || USA || 1885–1898 || George Eli Whitney of the [[East Boston]] [[Whitney Motor Wagon Company]] began to make a steam motor-vehicles in 1885 when he partly built one machine. In 1895 he began again and completed the 650&nbsp;lb carriage in October 1896. He built several more machines after that date. Whitney had gained experience while working on the [[Roper steam velocipede]]. For a short time Whitney's were manufactured by the [[Stanley Manufacturing Company]] as Stanley-Whitney's and by [[Everett Motor Carriage Company]] as Everett's<ref name=EarlyAmerican /> In 1899 Whitney sold the rights to a higher powered version of his car to [[Brown Brothers of England]].<ref>http://www.steamautomobile.com/ForuM/read.php?1,21097 retrieved 3 July 2015</ref>

==1914 to 1939==
The steam cars of this era up until the 1930s were the last steam powered production cars. The power advantages that steam had possessed were overtaken by the improvements to the petrol powered internal combustion engines.

The '''Penske PC-20''' was a [[Champ Car|CART]] [[Penske Racing]] car which competed in the [[1991 IndyCar season|1991]] and [[1992 IndyCar season|1992]] seasons. In 1991, it raced in all seventeen events, scoring 3 wins, two with [[Rick Mears]], and one with [[Emerson Fittipaldi]], placed 4th and 5th at the season's end respectively. The most remarkable success of the PC-20 was the [[1991 Indianapolis 500]] win by Mears, his 4th win at the Brickyard. The car was designed by [[Nigel Bennett (car designer)|Nigel Bennett]], his 4th for Penske Racing.<ref name="PC201">{{cite web
|publisher=forix.autosport.com
|url=http://forix.autosport.com/8w/penske-mercedes-pc23-car.html
|title=Mercedosaurus Rex at Indianapolic Park, Part 10: Penske PC23 - a home for the engine
}}</ref> In 1992, it also raced alongside the '''Penske PC-21'''.

==Racing history==
The PC-20 was powered by an [[Ilmor]]-[[Chevrolet]] V8 265A turbo engine and it debuted at the [[1991 Gold Coast IndyCar Grand Prix]] where it qualified 6th and 7th with Fittipaldi and Mears, respectively. In the race Mears scored a 3rd place, while Fittipaldi retired with drive shaft failure. After a 4th place finish in [[Grand Prix of Long Beach|Long Beach]] with Mears, and a 3rd place finish at [[XM Satellite Radio Indy 200|Phoenix]] with Fittipaldi, the PC-20 scored its biggest win at [[1991 Indianapolis 500]]. In qualifying, Mears clinched his 6th pole at Indy 500 (224.113&nbsp;mph<ref name="PC202">{{cite web
|publisher=www.race-database.com
|url=http://www.race-database.com/driver/career.php?driver_id=rmear1
|title=Rick Mears
}}</ref>). Mears battled with [[Michael Andretti]] during final stages of the race, who led Rick Mears by 15 seconds when a caution flag flies on lap 182. Andretti was able to make it to the pits for fuel under the yellow, while Mears lined up as the leader. Andretti then completed a daring pass around the outside of Mears into turn 1 on the restart. Exactly one lap later, Mears repeated the move on Andretti, passing him on the outside of turn one to re-take the lead. Another caution does not alter the result as Mears powered away again to his record-tying fourth Indianapolis 500 Victory,<ref name="PC204">{{cite web
|publisher=Penske Racing
|url=http://www.penskeracing.com/about/index.cfm?cid=15558
|title=Year-by-Year Highlights
}}</ref> tying A.J Foyt and Al Unser, Sr. During the rest of the season, the Penskes weren't able to compete with Michael Andretti dominance, who clinched the title with 8 season wins.<ref name="PC203">{{cite web
|publisher=www.race-database.com
|url=http://www.race-database.com/standings/standings.php?year=1991&series_id=4
|title=1991 CART PPG IndyCar World Series standings
}}</ref> Nevertheless, Fittipaldi won at [[Detroit Indy Grand Prix|Detroit]], and Mears scored a win at [[Firestone Indy 400|Michigan 500]], as confirmation of the PC-20's competitive form on long ovals.<ref name="PC205">{{cite web
|publisher=www.race-database.com
|url=http://www.race-database.com/results/results.php?year=1991&race=11&series_id=4
|title=1991 Marlboro 500
}}</ref>

In [[1992 IndyCar season|1992]], the PC-20 chassis was used by Penske Racing, as a third car for [[Paul Tracy]] in early stages of season (Tracy was driving the #4 car in second half of the season as replacement for injured Mears), and for entire season by [[Bettenhausen Racing]], with [[Tony Bettenhausen, Jr.]] and [[Stefan Johansson]] sharing the #16 car, with two 3rd places by Johansson as best results. It [[Team Penske#Complete CART FedEx Championship Series results|raced]] along the PC-21.

The PC-21 was instead powered by an [[Ilmor]]-[[Chevrolet]] 265B V8 turbo engine. It made its race debut in the Gold Coast, Australia, at the renamed [[1992 Daikyo IndyCar Grand Prix|Daikyo IndyCar Grand Prix]] where it finished first and second, driven by Fittipaldi and Mears, respectively. It is also the last car that Mears drove to his final career podium finish.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.johncummiskeyracing.com/?page_id=59|title=1992 Penske PC21-005|publisher=John Cummiskey Racing|accessdate=12 November 2014}}</ref>

===Ayrton Senna tests===
In December 1992, concerned by possibly being unable to secure a competitive drive for the {{f1|1993}} [[Formula One]] season, three-time world champion [[Ayrton Senna]] test-drove a PC-21<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ayrtonsenna.com.br/en/historias/dentro-das-pistas/provas-especiais/o-teste-com-a-penske-na-formula-indy|title=Penske test in Indy|publisher=Ayrton Senna Official|accessdate=9 November 2014}}</ref> at [[Firebird International Raceway]] in [[Chandler, Arizona]]. This test was facilitated by the fact that Penske Racing's lead driver was countryman Fittipaldi, and they were both sponsored by [[Marlboro (cigarette)#Other racing series|Marlboro]]. According to former Penske race engineer Nigel Beresford, Senna completed 24 laps in the car after which "He came back into the pits and said: 'Thank you very much, I've learned what I need to know.' Then he got out of the car and that was that." Senna covered the initial 14 laps relatively slowly to familiarize himself with the PC-21 since, unlike F1 racers of the time, [[Champ Car|IndyCars]] were markedly heavier and powered by a turbocharged engine. More crucially, they had a traditional transmission with clutch pedal and iron brakes, unlike the semi-automatic transmissions and carbon brakes used in F1. In his subsequent 10 laps using the same tyres, Senna set a best time was 49.09 seconds, which compared favourably with Fittipaldi's time of 49.70 seconds. The latter subsequently improved his time achieving 48.5 seconds, only after driving the new 1993 [[Penske PC-22]], which was also at his disposal during this test session.<ref>Fagnan, René (2012-08-27). [http://www.auto123.com/en/racing-news/penske-engineer-recalls-the-day-ayrton-senna-drove-an-indy-car?artid=147013 "Penske engineer recalls the day Ayrton Senna drove an Indy Car"]. auto123.com. Retrieved 2014-11-02.</ref>

'''Arma''' is 6x6 and 8x8 amphibious wheeled [[armoured combat vehicle]]<ref>https://www.otokar.com.tr/tr/urunler/urun_detay.aspx?urun=102</ref><ref>https://www.otokar.com.tr/tr/urunler/urun_detay.aspx?urun=104</ref> family designed and developed by [[Otokar]]. The vehicle is a modular multi-wheel configurable with high level of ballistic and mine protection due to its high hardness monocoque steel hull.<ref>http://www.otokar.com.tr/en/media_relations/p_haber_detay.aspx?haber=236</ref>

==Development==
Otokar developed the vehicle to target the Turkish Land Forces’ Special Purpose Tactical Wheeled Armoured Vehicle (''Özel Maksatlı Taktik Tekerlekli Zırhlı Araç, ÖMTTZA'') project. It is competing against two other vehicles in the shape of FNSS Defence Systems’ Pars and HEMA Endustri’s Anafarta, a variant of Patria’s 6×6 Armoured Modular Vehicle (AMV). Turkish Land Forces are expected to make a selection for its OMTTZA requirement by mid-2010 and subsequently procure 336 vehicles in a variety of versions: 30 for NBC reconnaissance, 36 radar carriers, 108 sensor carriers, 39 command vehicles and 108 fire-support vehicles, which could be armed with a manually operated 20&nbsp;mm cannon. Mobility tests with prototypes to date have included around 10,000&nbsp;km of running over varied terrain.<ref name=armytech>{{cite web|title=Arma 6x6|url=http://www.army-technology.com/projects/arma6x6/|work=Army-Technology|accessdate=9 May 2014}}</ref>

Otokar presented the first time to the public the Arma wheeled armoured vehicle at Eurosatory 2010. The ARMA is the latest product of Otokar’s design and development studies and a proof of Otokar’s ability to leverage its engineering, manufacturing and expertise across a large portfolio of armoured tactical vehicles. ARMA is a new product family within the Otokar’s the tactical wheeled armoured vehicle range with modular multi-wheel configuration. ARMA vehicle platform with superior tactical and technical features will be an outstanding and cost effective product among competitive products. Thanks to the high level of ballistic and mine protection as well as, the outstanding design allowing the integration of various types of weapon stations and mission equipment, ARMA will be an adaptable platform for evolving mission needs in a modern battlefield. ARMA vehicle’s development started in 2007 as a company funded development project for home and export markets. <ref name=armytech/>

Development studies from concept design till the end of test phases including qualification and validation processes, detailed design, computer aided engineering studies, are performed by Otokar. ARMA 6x6 is ready for full scale production and the family will be complemented by an 8x8 version late in 2010. In 2010, Turkish leading land systems manufacturer, Otokar received the first contract for its new 6x6 tactical armoured vehicle ARMA from abroad. The contract is valued in excess of $10.6 million including the vehicles, spare parts and training. Deliveries under this contract award are expected to be completed in 15 months. In June 2011, Otokar has been awarded a $63.2 million second contract for its new 6x6 tactical armoured vehicle ARMA.<ref name=armytech/>

===Foreign interest===
At [[International Defence Industry Fair|IDEF-2013]], the [[Azerbaijan Army]] expressed interest in the Arma 8x8 vehicle.<ref>[http://www.armyrecognition.com/may_2013_news_defence_army_military_industry_uk/azerbaijan_shows_interest_for_turkish_main_battle_tank_altay_and_8x8_armoured_vehicle_arma_1705134.html Azerbaijan shows interest for Turkish armored vehicles] - Armyrecognition.com, May 17, 2013</ref>

==Design==

===Armament===
The first prototype of the Arma is equipped with a circle ring support, armed with a single 12.7&nbsp;mm heavy machine gun. A [[tank destroyer]] variant sporting a 105mm cannon has also been exhibited.<ref>[http://www.otokar.com.tr/en/media_relations/p_haber_detay.aspx?haber=375 Otokar, Land Defence Systems House of Turkey, Unveils TULPAR Armoured Tracked Vehicle at IDEF]</ref> The Arma could probably be equipped a large range of manned and remote weapons stations.

===Protection===
No details have been released on its ballistic protection, but since it is required to be amphibious, armouring is not expected to exceed STANAG 4569 Level II, but its relatively high 425&nbsp;mm ground clearance should help achieve mine protection to Level IIIB or higher. ARMA’s ballistic and anti-mine protection is provided by high hardness monocoque steel hull and all personnel is seated on anti- mine seats.<ref name=armytech/>

===Propulsion===
The Arma 6x6 is motorised with a 450&nbsp;hp water-cooled turbo diesel capable of running on F-34 or F-54 fuel drives the wheels through an automatic gearbox and single-speed transfer box, giving it a top speed of 105&nbsp;km/h and a power/weight ratio of 24.3&nbsp;hp/tonne. This also powers the onboard 24 V DC electrical system, which incorporates two maintenance-free 125 Ah batteries and a 3.3&nbsp;kW converter. Arma’s front two axles are steerable enabling it to make a turning radius of 7.85 m and the vehicle rides on independent hydropneumatic suspension, offering respectable off-road mobility and comfort. It can negotiate 45-degree [[approach and departure angles]] leading onto 60 per cent inclines and 30 per cent side-slopes. It can also cross 1.2&nbsp;m-wide trenches and climb over 60&nbsp;cm obstacles.<ref name=armytech/>

===Accessories===
The ARMA can be transported by a C-130 plane. Standard equipment of ARMA 6x6 includes NBC protection system and air conditioning. ARMA can be driven in 6x6 or 6x4 modes depending upon the terrain conditions. The vehicle is amphibious and driven by 2 hyraulically driven propellors in water allowing a high seagoing performance with a pivot turn capability.<ref name=armytech/>

===Specifications===

'''Dimensions:''' Length, 6,428 m; Width, 2,708 m; Height, 2,223 m. 

'''Weight:''' 18,500&nbsp;kg

'''Speed:''' 105&nbsp;km/h on road

'''Range:''' 700&nbsp;km

'''Crew:''' 2 + 8 (10 if 8x8 variant) soldiers

'''Armor:''' Protection 12.5&nbsp;mm, mines and IDFs.

'''Armament:''' One 12.7&nbsp;mm or 7.62&nbsp;mm machine gun and more to be made

'''Accessories:''' NBC protection system, air conditioning

[[File:Nissan LEAF got thirsty.jpg|thumb|The [[Nissan Leaf]] has a [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) rated range of {{convert|73|mi|abbr=on}}]]
'''Range anxiety''' is the [[fear]] that a vehicle has insufficient range to reach its destination and would thus strand the vehicle's occupants.<ref name=RSC>{{cite web|title=Sustainable transportation based on electric vehicle concepts: a brief overview|url=http://www.researchgate.net/publication/224880220_Sustainable_transportation_based_on_electric_vehicle_concepts_a_brief_overview|last1=Eberle|first1=Ulrich|first2=Rittmar|last2=von Helmolt|publisher=[[Royal Society of Chemistry]] |date=2010-05-14| accessdate=2010-06-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cpuc.ca.gov/NR/rdonlyres/8B8F7624-1DF1-426B-847A-74255D3484D6/0/SCE_Comments_on_LDV_Electrification_White_Paper.pdf|title=Comments of Southern California Edison Company on the California Public Utilities Commission Staff’s White Paper, Light-Duty V|last=Backstrom|first=Michael|date=May 22, 2009|page=4|accessdate=26 June 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://schott.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/01/15/range-anxiety/|title=Range Anxiety|date=January 15, 2009<!--, 4:29 pm-->|accessdate=26 June 2010 | work=The New York Times | first=Ben | last=Schott}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/cwire/2010/05/07/07climatewire-will-lithium-air-battery-rescue-electric-car-37498.html|title=Will Lithium-Air Battery Rescue Electric Car Drivers From 'Range Anxiety'?|date=May 7, 2010|accessdate=26 June 2010 | work=The New York Times | first=Saqib | last=Rahim}}</ref> The term, which is primarily used in reference to [[battery electric vehicle]]s (BEVs), is considered to be one of the major barriers to large scale adoption of [[all-electric car]]s.<ref name="RSC"/><ref name="harv1">{{cite web|url=http://www.innovations.harvard.edu/cache/documents/11089/1108934.pdf|title=Policy options for electric vehicle  charging infrastructure in C40 cities|author=Jose Gomez-Ibane, Prof. Hermann Bennett & Dean John Haigh, Alfred Wiederer & Ronald Philip|work=Clinton Climate Initiative|publisher=Harvard|accessdate=23 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/leisure/2010/09/16/elecric-car-juice-pray-angel/|title=Electric Car Out of Juice? Pray for an Angel|last=Gordon-Bloomfield|first=Nikki|date=September 16, 201|publisher=TheCarConnection.com|accessdate=23 September 2010}}</ref> The term range anxiety was first reported in the press on September 1, 1997 in the ''San Diego Business Journal'' by Richard Acello referring to worries of [[GM EV1]] electric car drivers.<ref name=SDBJ>{{cite web|title=First public citation of range anxiety|url=http://www.wordspy.com/words/rangeanxiety.asp}}</ref> On July 6, 2010, [[General Motors]] filed to trademark the term, stating it was for the purpose of "promoting public awareness of electric vehicle capabilities".<ref>http://jalopnik.com/5626306/how-gm-will-use-fear-to-sell-you-a-chevy-volt</ref>  The [[Norwegian (language)|Norwegian]] equivalent ''rekkeviddeangst'' was assigned second place in a list of Norwegian "words of the year" for 2013 by the [[Norwegian Language Council]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://insideevs.com/range-anxiety-in-2nd-place-on-norways-words-of-the-year-list/|title="Range Anxiety" in 2nd Place on Norway’s "Words of the Year" List|publisher=Inside EVs|author=Eric Loveday}}</ref><ref>[http://www.sprakrad.no/Toppmeny/Aktuelt/Arets-ord-sakte-tv/ Årets ord: sakte-tv] (in Norwegian) via Quartz, [http://qz.com/159595/norway-electric-cars/ Norway is starting to have more electric cars than it can handle].</ref>

The main strategies to alleviate range anxiety among electric car drivers are the deployment of extensive [[charging infrastructure]], the development of higher battery capacity at a cost-effective price, [[battery swapping]] technology, use of [[range extender]]s, accurate navigation and range prediction and availability of free loaners for long trips.

==Responses to range anxiety==
[[File:Tesla Model S P85+ dashboard with zero range (cropped).JPG|thumb|The instrument panel of a [[Tesla Model S]] that has reached its destination just as the range went to zero]]
{{rquote|right|The range anxiety will limit the ability of the all electric car to be used in certain specific applications, even if the battery costs come down.|Bill Reinert|National manager of advanced technology at Toyota’s U.S. arm<ref name="reuter1">{{cite news|url=http://blogs.reuters.com/environment/2010/04/26/will-range-anxiety-limit-the-electric-car/|title=Will ‘range anxiety’ limit the electric car?|date=Apr 26, 2010<!-- 15:28 EDT-->|work=Analysis & Opinion|publisher=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=23 July 2010}}</ref>{{when|date=April 2013}}}}
The concern that users of all-electric vehicles may become stranded due to inadequate battery performance/capacity has led to public calls for extensive public [[charging infrastructure|charging networks]].<ref name="harv1" /> {{As of|2013|12}}, [[Estonia]] is the only country that had deployed an [[Electric vehicle network|EV charging network]] with nationwide coverage, with fast chargers available along highways at a minimum distance of between {{convert|40|to|60|km|abbr=on}}, and a higher density in urban areas.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/e9cb7536-f5f1-11e2-a55d-00144feabdc0.html?siteedition=intl#axzz2om3cwKaK|title=Infrastructure: Shortage of electric points puts the brake on sales|author=Adam Palin|work=[[Financial Times]]|date=2013-11-19|accessdate=2013-12-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://estonianworld.com/technology/estonia-becomes-the-first-in-the-world-to-open-a-nationwide-electric-vehicle-fast-charging-network/|title=Estonia becomes the first in the world to open a nationwide electric vehicle fast-charging network|author=KredEx|publisher=Estonian World|date=2013-02-20|accessdate=2013-12-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/feb/20/estonia-electric-car-charging-network|title=Estonia launches national electric car charging network|author=Adam Vaughan|work=[[The Guardian]] |date=2013-02-20|accessdate=2013-12-28}}</ref>

Electric vehicle manufacturers have sought to quell range anxiety concerns through increased battery capacities to extend the vehicle's [[all-electric range|range]].  REVA has a proprietary technology called "Revive", which is a battery reserve that can be released by electric vehicle users by texting or calling an operations center;.<ref name="harv1" />  Using a range extender solution, as implemented in the [[Chevrolet Volt]] or the [[BMW i3]],.<ref name=RSC /><ref Name=R1>{{cite web|title=The Voltec System - Energy Storage and Electric Propulsion|URL=http://www.researchgate.net/publication/262004450_The_Voltec_System_Energy_Storage_and_Electric_Propulsion|last1=Matthe|first1=Roland|last2=Eberle|first2=Ulrich|date=2014-01-01|accessdate=2014-05-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=AVL's Range Extender Allows Electrically Driven Ranges equal to those of Conventional Vehicles|url=http://www.atzonline.com/index.php;do=show/site=a4e/sid=18762177414d6a85de938b0568579942/alloc=1/id=9806}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=AVL Introduces New Modular Range Extender Technologies and Engineering Services (17 May 2009) | url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2009/05/avl-re-20090517.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The AVL Range Extender| url=https://www.avl.com/electrified-passenger-cars}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Driving Electrically: "AVL Pure Range Extender" for Electric Vehicles|url= https://www.avl.com/press-releases-2010/-/asset_publisher/F57c/content/avl-at-the-geneva-motor-show?redirect=%2Fpress-releases-2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title= AVL introduces its own Wankel rotary EV range-extender|url=http://green.autoblog.com/2010/07/16/avl-introduces-its-own-wankel-rotary-ev-range-extender/}}</ref>  Another method is the proposed Ridek [[modular vehicle]] approach whereby a vehicle's chassis could be exchanged for one containing a larger capacity battery at a network of chassis-exchange stations before embarking on a long journey.

Since lack of information can be a contributing factor, a good navigation system<ref>{{cite video | title=Real time driving range display | url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Sfigpo17pgw}}</ref> with knowledge of the battery capacity and remaining distance can minimize the fear. There is also the possibility to minimize the fear before buying a vehicle.<ref>{{cite web|title=iEV electric car simulator| url=http://dottribes.com/iEV}}</ref>

The [[American Automobile Association]] (AAA) has started a road-recharge pilot program in six cities, Knoxville, Los Angeles, Portland, San Francisco, Seattle and Tampa. EV-driving AAA members can use the truck’s level 3 charging capacity to recharge a [[Nissan Leaf]] to 80% capacity in 30 minutes.[http://www.torquenews.com/1079/test-ride-electric-car-free]

==Battery swapping==
[[Battery swapping]] is a strategy to avoid range anxiety that allows electric cars to extend their range through a battery switch station. At the station, the depleted battery is swapped for fully charged battery in about the same time that it takes to fill up a car with gasoline.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.betterplace.com/the-solution-switch-stations |author=[[Better Place]]|publisher=Better Place|accessdate=2014-04-21|title=How we give the electric car unlimited range}}</ref> Battery swapping is common in warehouses using electric [[forklift truck]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://us.simplenewz.com/industrial-electrical-vehicle-stalwarts-head-out-on-the-road--2009-03-08--ars-technica--30.672.7|title=Industrial electrical vehicle stalwarts head out on the road|date=2009-03-09|author=Ars Technica|publisher=simpleNews|accessdate=2013-04-21}}</ref>

As the electric car emerged as the main competing technology in the late 1890s until the 1920s, the concept of exchangeable battery service was first proposed as early as 1896 in order to overcome the limited operating range of electric cars and trucks. The concept was first put into practice by [[Hartford Electric Light Company]] through the GeVeCo battery service and initially available for electric trucks. The vehicle owner purchased the vehicle from General Vehicle Company (GVC, a subsidiary of the General Electric Company) without a battery and the electricity was purchased from Hartford Electric through an exchangeable battery. The owner paid a variable per-mile charge and a monthly service fee to cover maintenance and storage of the truck. Both vehicles and batteries were modified to facilitate a fast battery exchange. The service was provided between 1910 to 1924 and during that period covered more than 6 million miles. Beginning in 1917 a similar successful service was operated in [[Chicago]] for owners of Milburn Light Electric cars who also could buy the vehicle without the batteries.<ref name=HistEV>{{cite book|last=Kirsch|first=David A.|title=The Electric Vehicle and the Burden of History|location=[[New Brunswick]], [[New Jersey]], and [[London]]| year = 2000| pages= 153–162| publisher =[[Rutgers University Press]]|isbn=0-8135-2809-7}}</ref>

;Better Place
[[File:Better Place Charging Station IMG 6670.jpg|thumb|[[Better Place]]'s battery switching station in Israel]]
The [[Better Place]] network was the first modern commercial deployment of the battery switching model. The [[Renault Fluence Z.E.]] was the first electric car with a switchable battery available for the Better Place network in operation in Israel and Denmark.<ref>
{{cite web |url=http://www.betterplace.com/the-company-multimedia-photos/index/id/72157623854339020
 |title=Better Place. The Renault Fluence ZE
 |publisher=[[Better Place]]
 |date=2010-10-22
 |accessdate=2010-10-22}}
</ref> Better Place launched its first battery-swapping station in Israel, in [[Kiryat Ekron]], near [[Rehovot]] in March 2011.  The battery exchange process took five minutes.<ref name=JP240311>{{cite news|last=Udasin|first=Sharon|title=Better Place launches 1st Israeli battery-switching station|url=http://www.jpost.com/Sci-Tech/Article.aspx?id=213562|accessdate=2011-03-25|newspaper=The Jerusalem Post|date=24 March 2011}}</ref>  {{As of|2012|12}}, there were 17 battery switch stations fully operational in Denmark enabling customers to drive anywhere across the country in an electric car.<ref name="Better Place Delivers For Demanding Amsterdam Taxi Drivers">{{cite web|url=http://www.betterplace.com/the-company/press-room/Better-Place-Delivers-for-Demanding-Amsterdam-Taxi-Drivers | title=Better Place Delivers For Demanding Amsterdam Taxi Drivers | publisher=Better Place | accessdate=2012-12-19}}</ref>

By late 2012 the company began to suffer financial difficulties, and decided to put on hold the roll out in Australia and reduce its non-core activities in North America, as the company decided to concentrate its resources on its two existing markets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.drive.com.au/drive/motor-news/the-rise-and-fall-of-better-place-20130218-2emmn.html|title=The rise and fall of Better Place|author=David McCowen|publisher=Drive.com.au|date=2013-02-18|accessdate=2013-04-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.caradvice.com.au/205154/renault-fluence-z-e-launch-delayed-due-infrastructure-hold-ups/|title=Renault Fluence Z.E. launch delayed due to infrastructure hold-ups |author=Tim Beissmann |publisher=Car Advice|date=2012-12-13|accessdate=2013-04-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2013/02/bp-20130207.html|title=Better Place winding down ops in North America and Australia, to focus on Denmark and Israel
 |author= |publisher=[[Green Car Congress]]|date=2013-04-17|accessdate=2013-04-21}}</ref> Better Place filed for bankruptcy in Israel in May 2013. The company's financial difficulties were caused by the high investment required to develop the charging and swapping infrastructure, about {{USD|850}} million in private capital, and a market penetration significantly lower than originally predicted by Shai Agassi. Less than 1,000 Fluence Z.E. cars were deployed in Israel and around 400 units in Denmark.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/27/business/global/israeli-electric-car-company-files-for-liquidation.html?_r=0|title=Israeli Venture Meant to Serve Electric Cars Is Ending Its Run|author=Isabel Kershner|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=2013-05-26|accessdate=2013-05-27}}</ref><ref name=JPost052613>{{cite news|url=http://www.jpost.com/Business/Business-News/Death-of-Better-Place-Electric-car-co-to-dissolve-314380|title=Death of Better Place: Electric car co. to dissolve |author=Niv Elis|work=[[The Jerusalem Post]]|date=2013-05-26|accessdate=2013-05-30}}</ref> Under Better Place's business model, the company owns the batteries, so the court liquidator will have to decide what to do with customers who do not have ownership of the battery and risk being left with a useless car.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.globes.co.il/serveen/globes/docview.asp?did=1000846696&fid=1725|title=Better Place CEO: A missed opportunity|author=Dubi Ben-Gedalyahu|work=[[Globes]]|date=2013-05-26|accessdate=2013-05-28}}</ref>

;Tesla Motors
[[File:Tesla charging station with solar collector trimmed.jpeg|thumb|Panoramic view of [[Tesla supercharger]] rapid charging station in [[Tejon, California|Tejon Ranch, California]].]]
[[Tesla Motors]] designed its [[Tesla Model S|Model S]] to allow fast battery swapping.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://green.autoblog.com/2009/09/27/report-tesla-model-s-being-designed-with-battery-swaps-in-mind/|title=REPORT: Tesla Model S was designed with battery swaps in mind|author=Sebastian Blanco |publisher=[[Autoblog Green]]|date=2009-09-27|accessdate=2013-06-22}}</ref> In June 2013, Tesla announced their goal to deploy a [[battery swapping]] station in each of its [[Tesla Motors#Supercharger network|supercharging stations]]. At a demonstration event Tesla showed that a battery swap operation with the Model S takes just over 90 seconds, about half the time it takes to refill a gasoline-powered car used for comparison purposes during the event.<ref name=Swapping01>{{cite news|url=http://www.forbes.com/sites/markrogowsky/2013/06/21/tesla-90-second-battery-swap-tech-coming-this-year/|title=Tesla 90-Second Battery Swap Tech Coming This Year|author=Mark Rogowsky|work=[[Forbes]] |date=2013-06-21|accessdate=2013-06-22}}</ref><ref name=Swapping02>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2013/06/model2-20130621.html|title=Tesla Motors demonstrates battery swap in the Model S|author= |work=[[Green Car Congress]]|date=2013-06-21|accessdate=2013-06-22}}</ref>

The first stations are planned to be deployed along [[Interstate 5 in California]] where, according to Tesla, a large number of Model S sedans make the San Francisco-Los Angeles trip regularly. These will be followed by the [[Washington, DC]] to [[Boston]] corridor. Elon Musk said the service would be offered for the price of about {{convert|15|USgal}} of gasoline at the current local rate, around {{USD|60}} to {{USD|80}} at June 2013 prices. Owners can pick up their battery pack fully charged on the return trip, which is included in the swap fee. Tesla will also offer the option to keep the pack received on the swap and paying the price difference if the battery received is newer; or to receive the original pack back from Tesla for a transport fee. Pricing has not been determined.<ref name=Swapping01/>

==Range extender==
{{main|Range extender (vehicle)}}
;Series plug-in hybrids

[[Plug-in hybrid]]s (PHEVs), as opposed to pure electric cars, eliminate the range anxiety concerns because the gasoline engine serves as a back-up to recharge the battery to provide electric power to the electric motor, or to provide propulsion directly. Access to a regular fuel station guarantees that a PHEV has similar driving ranges as conventional gasoline-powered automobile when required.<ref name=DiscoveyG>{{cite web|url=http://auto.howstuffworks.com/range-anxiety-electric-cars1.htm|title=Could Range Anxiety Sabotage the Promise of Electric Cars?|publisher=Discovery's Planet Green|author= Michael Graham Richard|date=2009-10-14|accessdate=2010-03-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ceage.vt.edu/phev|title=Plug-In Hybrid Electric Vehicle (PHEV)|publisher=Center for Energy and the Global Environment, [[Virginia Tech]]|accessdate=2010-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hybridcars.com/plug-in-hybrid-cars|title=What Is A Plug-in Hybrid Car?|publisher=HybridCars.com|accessdate=2010-12-29}}</ref>

However, [[parallel hybrid|parallel]]s and series-parallel hybrids operate most of the time in [[blended mode]] while [[charge-depleting]]. Because the [[Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid]] operates as a [[series-parallel hybrid]], the [[U.S. EPA]] estimated its [[all-electric range]] for blended operation on a combination of electricity (from a fully charged battery pack) and gasoline as {{convert|11|mi|km|0|abbr=on}} until the battery is depleted.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1073585_2012-toyota-prius-plug-in-parsing-the-epa-efficiency-sticker|title=2012 Toyota Prius Plug-In: Parsing The EPA Efficiency Sticker|author=John Voelcker|publisher=Green Car Reports|date=2012-03-13|accessdate=2012-04-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2012/02/prius-20120228.html|title=Prius Plug-In eligibile for a $1,500 California consumer incentive plus $2,500 Federal tax credit|author=Toyota News Release|publisher=[[Green Car Congress]]|date=2012-02-28|accessdate=2012-04-12}}</ref> Other plug-in hybrids that operated mostly in blended mode are the [[Ford C-Max Energi]], [[Ford Fusion Energi]] and [[Honda Accord Plug-in Hybrid]].<ref name=EREV2013>{{cite web|url=http://www.plugincars.com/frost-sullivan-predicts-boom-sales-extended-range-electric-vehicles-2018-126357.html|title=Frost & Sullivan Predicts Boom in Extended-Range Electric Vehicles|author=Eric Loveday|publisher=PluginCars.com |date=2013-02-06|accessdate=2013-08-11}}</ref>
[[File:DCA 06 2012 Chevy Volt 4035.JPG|thumb|The [[Chevrolet Volt]] is a [[series hybrid|series]] [[plug-in hybrid]] referred by General Motors  as "an electric car with extended range."]]
On the other hand, [[series hybrid]]s,  also been referred to as extended-range electric vehicles (EREV)<ref name=R1/> or range-extended electric vehicles (REEV), are designed to be run mostly by the battery, but have a gasoline or diesel generator to recharge the battery when going on long trips. The [[Chevrolet Volt]], [[Fisker Karma]] and the upcoming [[Cadillac ELR]] are series plug-in hybrids.<ref name=EREV2013/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://green.autoblog.com/2009/04/02/greenlings-what-is-a-series-hybrid-extended-range-electric-vehi/|title=What is a series hybrid/extended range electric vehicle?|author= Sam Abuelsamid |publisher=[[Autoblog Green]]|date=2009-04-02|accessdate=2013-08-11}}</ref><ref name=GCR0312>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarreports.com/overview/fisker_karma_2012|title=2012 Fisker Karma -Review|author=John Voelcker|publisher=Green Car Reports|date=2012-03-13|accessdate=2013-08-11}}</ref>

;Chevrolet Volt
[[General Motors]] describes the [[Chevrolet Volt]] as an [[electric vehicle]] equipped with a "range extending" gasoline powered [[internal combustion engine|internal combustion engine (ICE)]] as a [[Engine-generator|genset]] and therefore dubbed the Volt an "Extended Range Electric Vehicle" or E-REV.<ref name=R1/><ref>{{cite web| url =http://wheels.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/06/25/chevrolet-volt-hits-road-ahead-of-schedule/| title = Chevrolet Volt Hits Road, Ahead of Schedule| work = [[The New York Times]]|date=2009-06-25| accessdate = 2011-06-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.mlive.com/auto/index.ssf/2010/10/is_the_chevrolet_volt_a_true_e.html | title = Is the Chevrolet Volt a true electric car? General Motors defends EV label| publisher = MLive.com| author = Jonathan Oosting| date = 2010-10-12|accessdate = 2010-06-02}}</ref>  In a January 2011 interview, the Chevy Volt's Global Chief Engineer, Pamela Fletcher, referred to the Volt as "an electric car with extended range."<ref>{{Cite news| last = Kuchment | first = Anna| date = January 2011 | accessdate = 2011-03-27| title = Practically Green: A Q&A with the Chevy Volt's Chief Engineer| periodical = Scientific American| publisher = Nature America| volume = 304 | issue = 1| page = 25| url =http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=practically-green| issn = 0036-8733}}</ref> The Volt operates as a purely electric car for the first {{convert|25|to|50|mi|km}} in [[charge-depleting]] mode. When the battery capacity drops below a pre-established threshold from full charge, the vehicles enters charge-sustaining mode, and the Volt's control system will select the most optimally efficient drive mode to improve performance and boost high-speed efficiency.<ref name=R1/><ref name=NYTVolt>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/17/automobiles/17VOLT.html?_r=1&scp=1&sq=Chevy%20Volt&st=cse|title=Sorting Myth From Fact as Volt Makes Its Debut|work=[[New York Times]]|author=Norman Mayersohn|date=2010-10-15|accessdate=2010-10-17}}</ref><ref name=MT101101>{{cite news
  | url = http://www.motortrend.com/features/editorial/1010_unbolting_the_chevy_volt_to_see_how_it_ticks/index.html| title = Unbolting the Chevy Volt to See How it Ticks| work = [[Motor Trend]]|author=Frank Markus| date = 2010-10-10| accessdate = 2010-10-11}}</ref>

In December 2012, two years after the Volt was launched, General Motors reported that cumulative miles driven in electric mode had passed the 100 million mark on November 30, 2012. The carmaker also reported that Volt owners have driven more than 65% percent of the time in all-electric mode, and on average they drive around {{convert|900|mi|abbr=on}}, or a month and a half, between fill-ups.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1080806_100-million-electric-miles-driven-by-chevy-volt-owners|title=100 Million Electric Miles Driven By Chevy Volt Owners |author=John Voelcker|publisher=Green Car Reports|date=2012-12-03|accessdate=2012-12-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.autoblog.com/2012/12/06/gm-says-chevy-volt-owners-have-logged-over-100-million-electric/|title=GM says Chevy Volt owners have logged over 100-million electric miles |author=Jeffrey N. Ross |publisher=[[Autoblog.com]]|date=2012-12-06|accessdate=2012-12-23}}</ref>  A 2014 analysis conducted by the [[ Idaho National Laboratory]] using a sample of 21,600 all-electric cars and plug-in hybrids, found that Volt owners traveled on average 9,112 miles in all-electric mode (e-miles) per year, while Leaf owners traveled 9,697 e-miles per year, despite the Volt's shorter [[all-electric range]], about half of the Leaf's.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.autonews.com/article/20150328/OEM05/303309999/calif.-considers-a-plea-for-plug-in-hybrids|title=Calif. considers a plea for plug-in hybrids|author=Gabe Nelson|work=[[Automotive News]]|date=2015-03-28|accessdate=2015-03-28}}</ref>
[[File:BMW i3 014 BSB 01 2015.JPG|thumb|Buyers of the [[BMW i3]] are offered a free loaner for longer trips and the option of a range-extender engine to avoid range anxiety.]]
;BMW i3

BMW i is offering the BMW i3 [[all-electric car]] with an optional gasoline-powered [[Range-extended vehicle|range extender]] engine added.<ref name=MA0710>{{cite web|url=http://www.motorauthority.com/blog/1047387_first-major-outing-for-bmw-megacity-vehicle-at-2012-london-olympic-games|title=First Major Outing For BMW Megacity Vehicle At 2012 London Olympic Games|author= Viknesh Vijayenthiran|publisher=Motor Authority|date=2010-07-20|accessdate=2010-07-23}}</ref> The range extender is powered by the same 647 cc two-cylinder gasoline engine used in the [[BMW C600 Sport and C650GT|BMW C650 GT]] motorcycle with a {{convert|9|L|abbr=on}} fuel tank. The range extender engine only engages when the battery level drops to a pre-specified point, acting purely as a generator to produce electricity to extend the range from {{Convert|80|to|100|mi|abbr=on|disp=flip}} to {{Convert|240|to|300|km|abbr=on}}<ref name=specs2014>{{cite web|url=http://insideevs.com/bmw-i3-range-extender-to-offer-up-to-87-more-miles-decreases-performance/|title=BMW i3 Range Extender To Offer Up to 87 More Miles, Decreases Performance|author=Jay Cole|publisher=InsideEVs.com |date=2013-07-29|accessdate=2013-07-29}}</ref><ref name=REX>{{cite news|url=http://www.autocar.co.uk/car-news/new-cars/first-rides-bmw-i8-hybrid-sportscar-and-all-electric-i3|title=First rides in BMW i8 hybrid sportscar and all-electric i3|author= Greg Kable|work=[[Autocar]]|date=2013-02-24|accessdate=2013-02-27}}</ref> The i3 performance in range-extending mode may be more limited than when it is running on battery power, as BMW clarified that the range extender is designed not for long-distance travel but purely as an emergency backup to keep the electric system going until the next recharging location.<ref name=GCR032013>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1082814_bmw-i3-electric-car-rex-range-extender-not-for-daily-use/page-2 |title=BMW i3 Electric Car: ReX Range Extender Not For Daily Use? |author=John Voelcker|publisher=Green Car Reports|date=2013-03-12|accessdate=2013-03-12}}</ref>

The range-extender option costs an additional {{USD|3,850}} in the United States,<ref name=NYT072013>{{cite news|url=http://wheels.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/07/29/bmw-unveils-i3-electric-car/?ref=automobiles&_r=1&|title=BMW Unveils i3 Electric Car|author=Benjamin Preston|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=2013-07-29|accessdate=2013-07-29}}</ref> an additional {{euro|4,710}} (~ {{USD|6300}}) in France,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.avem.fr/actualite-voiture-electrique-la-bmw-i3-officiellement-revelee-4303.html|title=Voiture électrique - La BMW i3 officiellement révélée|language=French|trans_title=Electric car - the BMW i3 officially revealed|author=Michaël Torregrossa|publisher= Association pour l'Avenir du Véhicule Electrique Méditerranéen (AVEM)|date=2013-07-30|accessdate=2013-07-31}}</ref> and {{euro|4,490}} (~ {{USD|6000}}) in the Netherlands.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://insideevs.com/official-bmw-i3-range-extender-option-adds-4490-euros-5919-us-to-price-tag-in-netherlands/|title=Official: BMW i3 Range Extender Option Adds 4,490 Euros ($5,919 US) to Price Tag in Netherlands|author=Eric Loveday|publisher=InsideEVs.com|date=2013-07-22|accessdate=2013-07-29}}</ref>

==Free loaners==
As a mitigation to range anxiety issues, some carmakers are offering the use of gasoline-powered standard car for free with the purchase of an electric vehicle to mitigate, thus allowing their customers to cover long trips on a certain number of days per year.

;BMW i3
[[File:2013-03-05 Geneva Motor Show 8283 Fiat 500e.jpg|thumb|The [[Fiat 500e]] purchase includes the use of a free loaner for longer trips for up to 12 days a year through the first three years of ownership.]]
[[BMW i]] is planning to offer additional mobility packages for trips where the range of an [[BMW i3]] would not be enough to allow customers to cover longer distances, including the provision of a conventional BMW vehicle on a given number of days per year.<ref name=Geneva2013>{{cite web|url=http://www.hybridcars.com/bmw-reveals-i3-coming-this-year/|title=BMW Reveals i3 Coming This Year |author=Philippe Crowe |publisher=HybridCars.com|date=2013-03-05|accessdate=2013-03-06}}</ref> In areas of high sales, BMW will also offer a roadside assistance program, which, instead of a tow, the assistance vehicle will provide a charge so the i3 can travel to the next charging station.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/16/business/with-i3-electric-car-bmw-tries-to-ease-range-anxiety.html?ref=automobiles&_r=0|title=With i3 Electric Car, BMW Tries to Ease Range Anxiety|author=Jack Ewing|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=2013-07-15|accessdate=2013-08-11}}</ref>

;Fiat 500e
In April 2013, Fiat North America announced a program to allow customers to cover longer travel distances, as each [[Fiat 500e]] purchase includes the use of rental vehicles for up to 12 days a year for free through the first three years of ownership. The program, called ePass, entitles 500e owners to a business account with enough points to rent a gasoline-powered standard car with [[Enterprise Holdings]], which owns [[Enterprise Rent-A-Car]], [[National Car Rental]] and [[Alamo Rent a Car]]. Fiat deposits additional points the following two years to extend the program.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.autonews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20130401/RETAIL07/304019968/buy-a-fiat-500e-use-alternate-cars-for-free#axzz2PDMDQzlJ |title=Buy a Fiat 500e, use alternate cars for free|author=Larry P. Vellequette |work=[[Automotive News]]|date=2013-04-01|accessdate=2013-04-07}}</ref><ref name=IEVs0413>{{cite web|url=http://insideevs.com/fiat-500e-purchasers-get-12-days-of-free-rentals-a-year-ev-to-be-priced-april-13th-on-sale-this-summer/|title=Fiat 500e Purchasers Get 12 Days Of Free Rentals A Year. EV To Be Priced April 13th, On Sale This Summer|author=Jay Cole|publisher=InsideEVs.com|date=2013-04-02|accessdate=2013-04-07}}</ref>

The '''T.25''' or Type 25 is a [[city car]] designed by [[Gordon Murray]], who created the [[McLaren F1]] supercar. The car made its first public appearance on June 28, 2010 at the UK's Smith School of Enterprise and the Environment in Oxford.<ref name="T25CNNRef">{{cite web|first= Matthew|last=Knight|authorlink=|coauthors=|title=Former F1 engineer unveils new city car|work=|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=2010-06-29|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/TECH/innovation/06/28/murray.green.car.launch/index.html?iref=mpstoryview&fbid=fhr0Cv7hUA6|format=|doi=|accessdate=2010-06-29}}</ref>

==Description==
At 2.4&nbsp;m (7'&nbsp;10½") long, 1.3&nbsp;m (4'&nbsp;3") wide and 1.6&nbsp;m (5'&nbsp;3") high; the T.25 is smaller than [[Daimler AG]]'s popular [[Smart (automobile)|Smart]].<ref>{{Cite web| last=Madslien|first=Jorn|authorlink=|coauthors=|title=F1 designer Gordon Murray unveils lightweight city car|work=|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=2010-09-19|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-11301831|format=|doi=|accessdate=2010-09-19}}</ref> The centralized driving position is also a feature of Murray's iconic McLaren F1; central instrumentation and controls are borrowed from Formula One. It is a Three Seater Car with a rear mounted three-cylinder petrol engine.<ref name="T25CNNRef"/> From the details released by its designer Murray, three T.25s can be parked in one standard UK parallel parking space, thereby increasing much needed urban parking capacity; in addition, its compact size will allow two T.25s to travel side-by-side (theoretically) in one UK motorway lane.<ref>[http://www.gordonmurraydesign.com/t25.php "T.25 - The Facts - Gordon Murray Design"]</ref>  

An [[electric car|electric version]], called the [[T.27]], was unveiled in June 2011.<ref name=GCC0711>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2011/06/gordon-murray-t27-unveiled-zytek-provides-more-details-on-25-kw-ev-powertrain.html|title=Gordon Murray T.27 unveiled; Zytek provides more details on 25 kW EV powertrain|publisher=[[Green Car Congress]]|date=2011-06-29|accessdate=2011-07-01}}</ref>  

Both cars are expected to have a top speed of {{convert|65|mph}}.<ref name=fox-revealed>{{cite web|first=Viknesh|last=Vijayenthiran|authorlink=|coauthors=|title=Gordon Murray's T25 Minicar Finally Revealed|work=|publisher=[[Green Car Reports]]|date=2010-06-28|url=http://www.greencarreports.com/blog/1046573_gordon-murrays-t25-minicar-finally-revealed|format=|doi=|accessdate=2010-06-29}}</ref>

Autocar Magazine Reported in August 2013 that the Murray T25 and T27 were confirmed for production, that the city cars project had been sold to manufacturer, and were estimated to be launched in 2016.<ref>http://www.autocar.co.uk/car-news/new-cars/murray-t25-and-t27-confirmed-production</ref>

The '''Amectran Exar-1''' was an [[electric car]] developed by Edmond X. Ramirez, Sr. in 1979.  The car was described by Amectran to be the "world's first real production, electronic powered automobile".  The car was highly praised by the [[United States Secretary of Transportation]].<ref>http://www.amectran.com/</ref><ref>http://www.rcc.us/Frua/1979_amectran_01.pdf</ref>

The '''Citroën DS4''' is the second model in the new premium ([[luxury vehicle]]) [[DS car marque|DS]] sub-brand created by [[Citroën]] to run alongside its mainstream cars. It was officially launched in 2011 internationally, but already on sale in some countries in late 2010.<ref name="PSA Annual Report 2012"/> Based upon the [[Citroën C4]] II, it features raised suspension to resemble a compact SUV and repositioned door handles to give a coupe-like silhouette. The rear windows are fixed, and do not slide or open outwards<ref>{{cite web|author=Post your review! |url=http://www.carwow.co.uk/car-reviews/Citroen/DS4 |title=Citroen DS4 reviews &#124; Expert and user reviews |publisher=carwow.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-02-03}}</ref>

The petrol engines that power the DS4 are a product of a collaboration between PSA and BMW.  All are 1,598 cc four-cylinder, 16-valve units. The base VTi 120 is normally aspirated and puts out {{Convert|120|PS|kW|0|abbr=on}}.  As its name implies it comes with variable valve timing.  The next engine up is the THP 155, essentially a turbo-charged version of the VTi.  It puts out {{Convert|156|PS|kW|0|abbr=on}} thanks to a twin-scroll turbocharger and dual overhead cams.  It is mated to a 6-speed manual transmission.  The most powerful gas engine available in the DS4 is the THP 200.  It's a variation of the THP 155 previously mentioned but pushed to {{Convert|200|PS|kW|0|abbr=on}}.

Citroen offers two diesel engines in the DS4 - the HDi 110, a 1,560 cc four-cylinder that puts out {{Convert|112|PS|kW|0|abbr=on}}.  The second is the four-cylinder HDi 160 also found in the Citroën C5 sedan.  It has a displacement of 1,997 cc and puts out {{Convert|163|PS|kW|0|abbr=on}}.

The DS4 is available with [[Start&Stop]] technology and Citroën says that the battery has been optimized to withstand up to 600,000 starting cycles. The trunk are 385 L and 1021 L with the back seat folded down on all models.

The DS4's styling has been very well received by the international press.

It was elected ''Most Beautiful Car of the Year'' at the International Automobile Festival,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.citroen.co.nz/news/general-news/citroen-ds4-voted-most-beautiful-car | title=Citroën DS4 Voted Most Beautiful Car of the Year | publisher=Citroën | accessdate=March 21, 2013}}</ref> beating [[BMW]]’s new [[BMW 5 Series (F10)|F10 5 Series]] and [[Honda]]'s new [[Honda CR-Z|CR-Z]] [[hybrid car]]. German magazine [[Auto Bild]] and its partner magazines throughout Europe have given it 1st Prize for Design in its category in Design Award contest.<ref>{{cite web|title=Citroën DS4 gets first prize in Auto Bild’s design award contest.|url=http://europeancarnews.com/2011/05/24/citroen-ds4-gets-first-prize-in-auto-bilds-design-award-contest/}}</ref>
