The '''Alfa Romeo Giulia''' (Type 952) is a [[Compact executive car|compact executive]] [[Sedan (car)|saloon car]] produced by [[Italy|Italian]] car manufacturer [[Alfa Romeo]]. It was premiered in June 2015, with market launch scheduled for February 2016,<ref name="QR 08/15">{{cite journal |first=Massimo |last=Nascimbene |title=I segreti di Giulia |trans-title=The secrets of Giulia |magazine=[[Quattroruote]] |pages=174–177 |date=August 2015 |publisher=Editoriale Domus |language=it}}</ref> and it is the first [[D-segment]] segment offering by Alfa Romeo after the end of production of the [[Alfa Romeo 159|159]] ended in 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.carmagazine.co.uk/car-news/first-official-pictures/alfa-romeo/alfa-romeo-giulia-2016-in-pictures-its-the-new-159/ |first=Tim |last=Pollard |title=Alfa Romeo Giulia (2016) in pictures and on video: it's the new 159! |website=[[Car (magazine)|Car]] |date=24 June 2015 |accessdate=16 January 2015}}</ref>
The Giulia is also the first high volume production Alfa Romeo in over two decades to use a [[longitudinal engine]]d [[rear-wheel drive]] platform, since the [[Alfa Romeo 75|75]] was discontinued in 1992.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.autoevolution.com/news/2016-alfa-romeo-giulia-tipo-952-quadrifoglio-verde-is-the-rebirth-of-alfa-romeo-video-photo-gallery-97073.html |title=2016 Alfa Romeo Giulia (Tipo 952) Quadrifoglio Verde is the Rebirth of Alfa Romeo |first=Mircea |last=Panait |website=autoevolution.com |date=24 June 2015 |accessdate=25 June 2015}}</ref>

==History==
The Giulia has been the subject of a long gestation and delayed launch dates, reportedly due to the design being sent back to the drawing board by [[Fiat Chrysler Automobiles]] (FCA) CEO [[Sergio Marchionne]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.carmagazine.co.uk/Secret-new-cars/Search-Results/Spyshots/Alfa-Romeo-Giulia-2014-CAR-Magazines-new-scoop/ |first=Tim |last=Pollard |title=Alfa Romeo Giulia (2014): CAR Magazine's new scoop |website=[[Car (magazine)|Car]] |date=23 July 2012 |accessdate=16 January 2015}}</ref>

The Alfa Romeo Giulia is the first model in the brand's relaunch plan, which involves a €5&nbsp;billion investment for an eight car line-up and a worldwide sales targets of 400,000 by 2018—up from 74,000 in 2013.<ref name="wsj 24/06/15">{{cite web |url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/with-new-alfa-romeo-sedan-fiat-chrysler-looks-for-rebirth-of-a-brand-1435172384 |title=With New Luxury Sedan, Fiat Chrysler Looks for Rebirth of a Brand |first=Eric |last=Sylvers |website=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=24 June 2015 |accessdate=25 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://blog.caranddriver.com/alfa-romeo-5-year-plan-awdrwd-lineup-and-8-new-products-by-2018-semi-autonomy-from-fiat-chrysler/ |title=Alfa Romeo 5-Year Plan: AWD/RWD Lineup and 8 New Products by 2018, Semi-Autonomy from Fiat-Chrysler |first1=Alexander |last1=Stoklosa |first2=Andrew |last2=Wendler |website=[[Car and Driver]] |date=6 May 2015 |accessdate=25 June 2015}}</ref> It is underpinned by an all-new, longitudinal-engined platform developed for Alfa Romeo—codenamed "Giorgio".<ref name="QR 08/15" />
Development of the Giulia, and indeed of the entire "Giorgio" project, has been overseen by [[Ferrari]] technical director and secondee, Philippe Krief.<ref name="QR 08/15" />

The Giulia was unveiled to the press at the [[Museo Storico Alfa Romeo]] in [[Arese]], on 24 June 2015, at an event which included a rendition of ''[[Nessun Dorma]]'' by Italian tenor [[Andrea Bocelli]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lastampa.it/2015/06/25/multimedia/motori/per-la-nuova-giulia-bocelli-canta-nessun-dorma-g1KwwzfgjSOcfkRTP6jNaL/pagina.html |title=Per la nuova Giulia Bocelli canta "Nessun dorma" |trans-title=For the new Giulia Bocelli sings "Nessun Dorma" |website=[[La Stampa]] |date=25 June 2015 |language=it |accessdate=8 August 2015}}</ref> The occasion coincided with company's 105th anniversary,<ref name="wsj 24/06/15" /> which also saw the company debuted a restyled logo for all future Alfa Romeo models.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.alvolante.it/news/alfa-romeo-giulia-gli-interni-341872 |title=Alfa Romeo Giulia: gli interni|trans-title=Alfa Romeo Giulia: the interior |website=alvolante.it |date=26 June 2015 |language=it |accessdate=26 June 2015}}</ref> The Giulia was also presented under the new ''La meccanica delle emozioni'' slogan ("the mechanics of emotions" in Italian).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.alfaromeo.com/com/alfa-thevoiceofgiulia |title=Alfa Romeo USA &#124; Official Alfa Romeo Website |website=alfaromeo.com |accessdate=31 July 2015}}</ref>

The car will be assembled at [[FCA Italy]]'s [[Fiat Cassino Plant|Cassino Plant]] in ([[Province of Frosinone|Frosinone]]), in central Italy.<ref name="rainews24" /> Pre-series production is scheduled for late August 2015, while full production and sales are scheduled for November 2015 and February 2016, respectively.<ref name="QR 08/15" />

==Models==
[[File:"15 - ITALY - New Logo Alfa Romeo on rear trunk of Alfa Romeo Giulia 2015.jpg|thumbnail|The restyled company logo, which debuted with the new Giulia]]
The Giulia uses a [[front-engine, rear-wheel-drive layout]], featuring an even 50% front and 50% rear [[weight distribution]].<ref name="autocar 24/06/15" />
Suspension is of the [[Double wishbone suspension|double wishbone]] type at the front and [[Multilink suspension|multilink]] at the rear.<ref name="autocar 24/06/15" />
All Giulia models employ a [[Carbon-fiber-reinforced polymer|carbon fibre]] [[drive shaft]] as well as [[aluminium alloy]] shock towers, suspension components, [[Fender (vehicle)|front wings]] and [[Vehicle door|doors]].<ref name="topgear">{{cite web |url=http://www.topgear.com/uk/car-news/alfa-giulia-will-the-plan-succeed-2015-06-25 |title=Opinion: will Alfa’s masterplan succeed? |first=Paul |last=Horrell |website=[[Top Gear (magazine)|topgear.com]] |date=25 June 2015 |accessdate=25 June 2015}}</ref><ref name="alfaromeopress" />
[[Four-wheel drive]] models will also be offered.<ref name="autocar 24/06/15" /><ref name="C&D 24/06/15">{{cite web |url=http://www.caranddriver.com/news/2017-alfa-romeo-giulia-photos-and-info-news |title=2017 Alfa Romeo Giulia: A Stunning Sports Sedan Headed for America |first=Tony |last=Quiroga |website=[[Car and Driver]] |date=June 2015 |accessdate=25 June 2015}}</ref>

Besides the high-performance Quadrifoglio's [[twin turbo]] 90º V6, the engine line-up will comprise [[turbocharged]] [[V6 engine|six-]] and [[Inline-four engine|four-cylinder]] [[petrol engine]]s, as well as six- and four-cylinder [[Diesel engine|turbodiesels]].<ref name="topgear" />
A four-cylinder and a V6, the latter different from the Quadrifoglio's and with a 60º angle between the [[cylinder bank]]s,<ref name="QR 08/15" /> will built in FCA Italy's [[Termoli]] plant.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lastampa.it/2015/04/08/economia/fca-a-termoli-due-nuovi-motori-per-lalfa-VOkAbHGyYTMIV1xIIJ2WQI/pagina.html|title=Fca, a Termoli due nuovi motori per l’Alfa|trans-title=Fca, at Termoli two new engines for Alfa|website=[[La Stampa]] |date=8 April 2015 |language=it |accessdate=25 June 2015}}</ref>

The first models on sale from February 2016 will be a 2.2 turbodiesel and the 2.9 V6 Quadrifoglio.<ref name="QR 08/15" />

===Giulia Quadrifoglio===
The high-performance Giulia Quadrifoglio ("Cloverleaf") was the first model in the new Giulia range to be revealed, in June 2015. It is powered by an all-[[aluminium]], [[twin-turbocharged]] 90° V6 petrol engine, with a single cylinder displacement of just under half a litre,<ref name="QR 08/15" /> for a total of 2.9–3.0&nbsp;L. This engine was developed exclusively for the Quadrifoglio by Ferrari technicians<ref name="alfaromeopress" /> and it is related to Ferrari's own twin-turbo [[Ferrari F154 engine|F154 V8]].<ref name="QR 08/15" /> It produces {{convert|510|PS|kW bhp|0}},<ref name="autocar 24/06/15" /> and around {{convert|600|Nm|lbft|-1|abbr=on}} of torque.<ref name="QR 08/15" /> The V6 features [[Variable displacement|cylinder deactivation]], being able of switching off three of its six cylinders.<ref name="QR 08/15" />

According to the manufacturer, the Giulia Quadrifoglio can accelerate from a standstill to {{convert|100|km/h|mi/h|0|abbr=on}} in 3.9&nbsp;seconds<ref name="alfaromeopress">{{cite web |url=http://www.alfaromeopress.com/press/article/117019 |title=World preview of the Alfa Romeo Giulia |website=alfaromeopress.com |type=press release |publisher=[[Fiat Chrysler Automobiles]] |date=24 June 2015 |accessdate=24 June 2015}}</ref><ref name="C&D 24/06/15" /> The car's power to weight ratio is 3&nbsp;kg/PS,<ref name="24ore">{{cite web |url=http://www.motori24.ilsole24ore.com/Auto-Novita/2015/06/Alfa-Romeo-nuova-giulia-quadrifoglio.php |first=Mario| last=Cianflone |title=Alfa Romeo è tornata: ecco la nuova Giulia da 510 cavalli |trans-title=Alfa Romeo is back: here is the new 510 horsepower Giulia |website=[[Il Sole 24 Ore]] |date=24 June 2015 |language=it |accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref> also thanks to the fact that, in addition to the other models' composite and light alloy parts, the Quadrifoglio has a carbon fibre roof and [[Hood (vehicle)|engine bonnet]].<ref name="topgear" />

[[File:" 15 - ITALY - Alfa Romeo Giulia QV (pre series) at Museo Alfa Romeo Arese world premiere 05.jpg|thumbnail|Rear view of the Giulia Quadrifoglio]]
From the front, the Quadrifoglio distinguishes itself from the rest of the range by a specific front bumper—with a carbon fibre splitter and enlarged air intakes for the twin [[intercooler]]s and for the brakes—and by a bonnet pierced by two cooling outlets for the engine bay. On the sides, the front [[Fender (vehicle)|wings]] also have outlets to extract air from the [[wheel well]]s, and bear [[Alfa Romeo#The Quadrifoglio|Quadrifoglio]] badges; the side skirts are specific to the model, as are the 19-inch<ref name="QR 08/15" /> alloy wheels. At the rear a low profile carbon fibre spoiler is applied to the boot lid, and a rear diffuser makes up the lower half of the bumper, flanked by quadruple exhaust tips. Working in conjunction with the faired-in underside, the [[Diffuser (automotive)|diffuser]] is fully functional in generating [[downforce]]—as at the front is the "Active Aero Splitter",<ref name="24ore" /> which can vary its [[angle of attack]] by 10º, moved by electric motors.<ref name="QR 08/15" /> Alfa Romeo claims both of these aerodynamic features to be firsts in the Giulia's market segment.<ref name="QR 08/15" />

Mechanically, this model is fitted with a [[torque vectoring]] rear [[Differential (mechanical device)|differential]],<ref name="C&D 24/06/15" /> able to send 100% of the torque to the left or right wheel,<ref name="carmagazine 10/07/15">{{cite web|url=http://www.carmagazine.co.uk/car-news/industry-news/alfa-romeo/seven-surprises-on-new-alfa-romeo-giulia-revealed-by-chief-engineer/ |first=Phil |last=McNamara |title=Seven surprises on new Alfa Romeo Giulia revealed by chief engineer |website=carmagazine.co.uk |date=10 July 2015 |accessdate=1 September 2015}}</ref> and, on the model which debuted in July 2015, a six-speed [[manual transmission]].<ref name="QR 08/15" /> The braking system uses [[Ceramic matrix composite|carbon ceramic]] rotors,<ref name="alfaromeopress" /> six-pot front and four-pot rear [[Brake caliper|calipers]], and auxiliary rear calipers for the [[parking brake]]. The [[electronic stability control]] and the traditional [[Vacuum servo|brake servo]] are combined in a single electromechanical system.

Inside, the dashboard is part-trimmed in leather and carbon fibre trim and the engine start button is located on the multi-function steering wheel. In addition, the driver is offered Alfa Romeo's "DNA" dynamic control selector, which is placed on the centre dashboard.<ref name="QR 08/15" /> Driving modes include the traditional "'''D'''ynamic", "'''N'''eutral" and "'''A'''dvanced" modes, plus new "Efficient" (for increased fuel economy) and "Racing" (for high performance).<ref name="24ore" />

The '''Suzuki Fronte 800''' was a 2-stroke [[subcompact]] car built by the Suzuki Motor Corporation in the latter half of the 1960s.

== History ==
Introduced in August 1965 (and on sale by December), the Fronte 800 was an attempt at competing in a higher market segment than the Suzulight [[Kei car|Kei jidosha]] class offerings. The name from its smaller engined brother, the [[Suzuki Fronte#Suzulight Fronte|Fronte]], was retained to aid the publicity effort. A four-door 700&nbsp;cc prototype was shown at the 1962 Tokyo Motor Show, clothed in a body designed by [[Pietro Frua]], reminiscent of his [[Maserati Quattroporte#Quattroporte I (1963–1969)|Maserati Quattroporte I]] and {{link-interwiki|vertical-align=sup | en = Glas 1700 | lang = de | lang_title = Glas 1700}} saloons.<ref name=CGweb>{{Cite web | author = Akira Tanuma | archiveurl=http://www.webcg.net/WEBCG/essays/korekiri/e0000018015.html | title=Hand Made People's Car #16: Suzuki Fronte 800 | date= 2003-05-03 | url=http://www.webcg.net/WEBCG/essays/korekiri/e0000018015.html | publisher=Car Graphic web | archivedate= 2010-07-28 }}</ref> This line of development was not followed, with work on the '''Y4''' prototype instead begun in 1962, another prototype appearing at the 1963 [[Tokyo Motor Show]]. Imminent production was announced, but at the '64 Motor Show another pre-production model was shown, with sales promised for the spring of the following year. Actual production, never but in a small scale and largely hand built, began in December 1965.<ref name=CGweb/>

=== Engine ===
The three-cylinder, two-stroke 785&nbsp;cc engine was very similar to that of the 796&nbsp;cc [[DKW Junior]]/F11, with a {{Convert|0.5|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} smaller bore and exactly the same stroke.<ref name=SuzukiStory>Ozeki, Kazuo. ''Suzuki Story: Small Cars, Big Ambitions''. Miki Press: 2007, p. 137-141. ISBN 978-4-89522-503-8</ref> Top speed was 115&nbsp;km/h,<ref>''Tutte le Auto del Mondo 1967'' claims a top speed of 120&nbsp;km/h.</ref> and the car was only available with a fully synchronized 4-speed column mounted manual transmission.<ref name=CarGraphic>''Car Graphic: Car Archives Vol. 1, '60s Japanese/American Cars''. Nigensha: 2000, p. 40. ISBN 978-4-544-09171-7</ref> Introductory price was ¥465,000, with a ¥545,000 DeLuxe version also available.

[[File:Suzuki-Fronte800rear.JPG|thumb|left|Rear view of Fronte 800]]
The body was a modern unibody design, only available as a two-door sedan. While rumoured to have been executed by [[Giovanni Michelotti|Michelotti]], design was credited to Suzuki chief designer Sasaki Toru (佐々木亨), who crafted a modern "soapbox" design with large glass surfaces. Suspension was an independent torsion bar design on all four wheels, with wishbones up front and trailing arms in rear.<ref name=CarGraphic/> Brakes were drums all around.<ref name=Ruiz>Ruiz, Marco. ''The Complete History of the Japanese Car: 1907 to the Present''. ERVIN srl., Rome: 1986, p.166. ISBN 0-517-61777-3</ref> Sales were slow, as the car competed directly with more popular cars like the [[Toyota Publica]] which were not handicapped by the Suzuki's by now outmoded two-stroke engine - while kei car buyers did not mind putting up with such a construction, car buyers in this segment were by now demanding more.<ref name="Meyer5">{{cite journal | journal = AutoPhyle | issue = Spring, #2 | year = 1996 | volume = 5 | last = Meyer | first = Allan G. Y. | pages = 5–6 | title = Suzuki Fronte, Queen For a Day | location = Watsonville, CA }}</ref>

===History===
The 800 did not see a lot of updates during its production life: in April 1966 it gained separate front seats, as of June reclining such were available.<ref name=SuzukiStory/> A version with separate front seats received a floor mounted shifter.<ref>''Tutte le Auto del Mondo 1967''. '''Quattroruote Speciale''', Editoriale Domus, Milan: 1967, p. 282.</ref> By August 1966 the Standard version was cancelled, leaving only the DeLuxe. Production was cancelled in April 1969 after less than 3,000 were built in four years;<ref>{{cite book | editor = ＧＰ企画センター [GP Planning Center] | trans_title = History Timeline of the Japanese automobile | title = 日本自動車史年表 | publisher = GP Publications | location = Tokyo, Japan | year = 2006 | page = 101 | isbn = 978-4-87687-286-2}}</ref> slow sales, need for capacity to produce the hit [[Suzuki Fronte#Fronte 360|Fronte 360]], and a perceived inability to compete with the large domestic manufacturers in what had become the most closely contested Japanese market segment meant the end of the 800. By the time of the 1969 Tokyo Motor Show, the Fronte 800 had disappeared from Suzuki's pricelists, with 2717 built and 2612 sold.<ref name=SuzukiStory/> Suzuki was to focus exclusively on [[Kei car]]s (and bigger engined Kei iterations) until the 1983 introduction of the [[Suzuki Cultus|Cultus]].

The 1980s Suzuki Fronte hatchback was also marketed as the "Fronte 800" in some smaller markets such as Chile. Most countries outside of Japan received this particular car as the "Alto".

==Fronte 1100==
A 1.1 litre version, the '''C20''', was developed for a planned "Fronte 1100" model. The engine's design parallelled that of the {{convert|68|PS|kW|0|abbr=on|lk=on}} 1,175&nbsp;cc [[DKW F102]], but the triple [[Solex]]-carburetted {{convert|80|PS|kW|0|abbr=on}} C20 was considerably more powerful. The front disc-brake equipped Fronte 1100's top speed was {{Convert|160|km/h|mi/h|0|abbr=on}}, but tiny Suzuki chose not to continue competing head on with the offerings of bigger manufacturers such as Toyota and Nissan.<ref name=SuzukiStory/> Additionally, with the market failure of the F102 the writing was on the wall for the two-stroke engine in cars any larger than the very smallest.

The '''Büssing A5P''' was an [[Armored car (military)|armoured car]] produced in [[German Empire|Germany]] during [[World War I]].

==History==
The [[Büssing]] company had received its first orders of [[military vehicle]]s in 1910, producing [[artillery tractor]]s and supply trailers. By November 1914, the [[German Army (German Empire)|German Army]] had become aware of the potential of the armoured car by the hit-and-run tactics employed by the Belgians with the [[Minerva Armored Car|Minerva]]. The ''[[Oberste Heeresleitung]]'' decided to produce its own armoured vehicle and the manufacturing companies [[Ehrhardt E-V/4|Ehrhardt]], [[Daimler-Motoren-Gesellschaft|Daimler]] and Büssing were requested to develop an armoured car with [[all-wheel drive]]. 

During 1915, Büssing delivered the ordered prototype. In contrast to the Belgian armoured cars, the A5P was a massive vehicle, using a 'double-ended' layout that could at least pose a tactically useful high ground clearance. Its powerplant was Büssing's successful 6-cylinder truck engines. It had a large steel armoured body and was crewed by 10 men. 6 of the crew operated three 7.92&nbsp;mm [[machine gun]]s, usually the [[MG 08]] or [[Bergmann MG 15nA machine gun|MG 15nA]]. Some vehicles even received two 20&nbsp;mm [[cannon]]. 

In 1916, the A5P began production. Nevertheless, the German Army considered the Ehrhardt design more effective to fulfil the demanded operational tasks. As a result, production was stopped after three cars built. These A5P served in a column on the [[Eastern Front (World War I)|Eastern Front]] until 1917.

The '''Lola B11/40''' is an open-top [[Le Mans Prototype]] (LMP) built by [[Lola Cars|Lola Cars International]]. It is the first car to be designed to the new [[Automobile Club de l'Ouest]] (ACO) LMP2 "low cost formula" where cars will be powered exclusively by production series engines with a cap of €75,000 on the engine and €325,000  – €400,000 for a complete car.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lemans.org/en/news/2011-LE-MANS-24-HOURS-REGULATIONS_628.html|title=THE 2011 LE MANS 24 HOURS REGULATIONS |publisher=Lemans.org |accessdate=21 July 2010}}</ref> Engine options that will be available include [[BMW]], [[Ford]], [[Honda|HPD]], [[Jaguar Cars|Jaguar]], [[Nissan]] and [[Toyota]].

==Development==

Announced on 21 July 2010,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lolacars.com/newsstory.asp?NewsId=260 |title=Lola Group News: Lola launches B11/40 LMP2 |publisher=Lolacars.com |accessdate=21 July 2010}}</ref> the B11/40 is a [[Carbon fibre]] open-top [[monocoque]] race car features an all-carbon bodykit, quick-release removable rear bodywork which includes a stabilisation fin on the engine cover which is a safety requirement of the new regulations.

The '''Mitsuoka Like''' (雷駆) is a five-door [[hatchback]] [[electric car]] produced by the [[Japan]]ese automaker [[Mitsuoka]] Motors since 2010.{{Citation needed|date=October 2010}} It is based on the [[Mitsubishi i MiEV]]. 

It was unveiled in 2010 and was discontinued in 2012. The wheelbase was extended to help accommodate five passengers, unlike the i Miev, which only seats four. Its distinctive front styling separates it from other rebadged i Mievs, including the Citroen C-Zero and the Peugeot Ion. It was priced at USD 55,000, before a Japanese tax credit, which lowered the priced to USD 14,550. 

The name "Like" is an indirect romanization of {{nihongo||雷駆|Raiku|literally "thunder drive"}}, which is a portmanteau of 雷 (thunder, referring to its electric powertrain) and 駆 (drive, more specifically drivetrain).

The '''GTA Spano''' is a Spanish [[supercar]] built in [[Valencia, Spain|Valencia]] by the company [[GTA Motor]], a sister company to [[GTA Motor Competición]]. It began as a secret project in 2005, and was first released to the public in 2008 when the model was presented under the name of GTA Concept. The first units were manufactured and delivered at the end of 2010.{{Citation needed|date=November 2010}}

Since 2008, a large group of engineers worked on the project under the direction of Domingo Ochoa, who has over 15 years of experience in racing cars, a key point for the technical development of the vehicle. The car has several worldwide patents (five fully processed according to the last presentation of the company) and will make use of technology never before implemented in a Spanish vehicle.

In February 2008 a public and official presentation of the project was made through a model in the [[City of Arts and Sciences]] in Valencia. In August of that year, the first prototype began testing at the [[Circuit Ricardo Tormo]]. From 19 to 25 April 2010, the car was officially presented at the Top Marques Monaco lounge. The first units were manufactured and delivered at the end of 2010.{{Citation needed|date=February 2013}} Only 99 units will be built in order to maintain its exclusivity. Their production is carried out exclusively in [[Riba-roja de Túria]], the town where GTA Motor has established its main facilities.

The latest version of the car is set to be featured at the [[Geneva motor show#2013|2013 Geneva Motor Show]] with a {{convert|900|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}} engine with 1000 Nm of torque, which has been electronically limited. 

The GTA Spano played a role in the 2014 film [[Need for Speed (film)|Need For Speed]].

==Technical specifications==
The chassis was made by combining [[carbon fibre]], [[titanium]], and [[Kevlar]], making it a benchmark in the industry. The Spano is powered by a supercharged version of the [[Dodge Viper]]'s V10 engine,<ref name=cdrev>{{cite web|url=http://www.goauto.com.au/mellor/mellor.nsf/story2/38E2759976E4BA62CA2575BB0025A5E9|title=Future Models - GTA 2010 Spano|work=GoAuto.com.au|accessdate=2009-05-19}}</ref> mounted in a rear longitudinal position and puts out 820&nbsp;hp and 960 Nm of torque.

The Spano is characterized by the exclusivity of its lines and its high performance. The car is known to reach an unofficial top speed in excess of {{convert|350|kph|mph|0|abbr=on}}, and 0–100&nbsp;kp/h takes less than three seconds.

The Spano has a good power-to-weight ratio of .62&nbsp;hp/kg (using bio-ethanol) and large wheels, namely 255/35R19 in the front and 335/30R20 at the rear, with [[Pirelli]] PZero tires as a standard option. Braking is carried out by six-piston calipers from [[AP Racing]] with a pneumatic [[Anti-lock braking system|ABS]] system and carbon-ceramic discs 380&nbsp;mm in diameter.

== Design ==
The exterior design was carried out by Valencian designer Sento Pallardó. Its panoramic glass roof, which has a patented system of opacity and lighting, gives a sense of spaciousness inside.

[[File:GTA Spano 2.jpg|150px | thumb | right | GTA Spano headlight detail]]

The '''Williams FW08''' was a [[Formula One]] car designed by [[Patrick Head]] which debuted at the [[1982 Belgian Grand Prix]] held at the [[Circuit Zolder|Zolder]] circuit. An evolution of the [[Williams FW07|FW07]] that it replaced, the car was used by [[Finland|Finnish]] driver [[Keke Rosberg]] to win the [[1982 Formula One season|1982]] [[List of Formula One World Drivers' Champions|World Drivers' Championship]].

The '''FW08B''' was a six-wheeled (4 driven wheels at the rear and 2 undriven wheels at the front) variant that originated from the [[Williams FW07|FW07D]] (also six-wheeled). It never raced. Patrick Head specifically said that the reason it was banned was because "someone in a FOCA meeting said it would drive up costs and cause chaos during pitstops". The FIA promptly limited the number of wheels for all cars to four, of which only 2 may be driven.<ref>http://www.yallaf1.com/2011/03/18/remembering-the-williams-f1-6-wheeler/</ref><ref>http://f1rejects.com/hall/beta/index.html</ref>

The car was updated for the [[1983 Formula One season]] to become the '''FW08C'''. Under new regulations all [[Ground effect in cars|ground effect]]s were out and flat bottom cars were in meaning nearly all the cars in F1 had to be heavily modified or replaced and the FW08 was no different. Against the turbo cars of [[Renault F1|Renault]], [[Brabham]] and [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]], Williams were not expected to do as well as they did. Rosberg opened the season with pole position at the [[1983 Brazilian Grand Prix|Brazilian Grand Prix]] (the last for a [[Cosworth DFY]] engined car) and scored the cars last win with a great drive at [[1983 Monaco Grand Prix|Monaco]]. He would eventually finish 5th in the Drivers' Championship while Williams would finish 1983 in 4th place, the best of the [[Cosworth]]-powered cars.

The FW08C also has the distinction of being the first Formula One car ever driven by [[Ayrton Senna]] at [[Donington Park]] in July 1983, after he badgered team boss Frank Williams for a test after being sat beside him on a flight. Senna completed 40 laps and lapped the circuit faster than anyone else had managed in the car, including 1983 race drivers Rosberg and [[Jacques Laffite]]. However, Williams team was not able to offer Senna a drive for {{f1|1984}} as Rosberg and Laffite were under contract and the [[Brazilian people|Brazilian]] signed to the [[Toleman]] team instead. Senna would not drive another Williams until he fatefully signed to drive for the team in {{f1|1994}}.

[[File:Williams FW08C Mont-Tremblant Esses.JPG|thumb|left|350px|A Williams FW08C, pictured in 2010. Note the much reduced sidepods in comparison to the earlier FW08 pictured above right.]]

The FW08C was retired after the [[1983 European Grand Prix]] at [[Brands Hatch]]. A third car was actually raced by the team at this race and was driven to 13th place by [[Jonathan Palmer]]. It was replaced by the [[Honda Racing F1|Honda]] powered [[Williams FW09|FW09]] for the last race of the season in [[1983 South African Grand Prix|South Africa]].

Early in 1983, Rosberg drove his FW08C to victory in the [[1983 Race of Champions|Race of Champions]] at Brands Hatch. To date this is the last non-championship Formula One race held.

In 1985 two FW08C were entered by PMC Motorsport in some races of the [[1985 International Formula 3000 season|Formula 3000 championship]], driven by [[Thierry Tassin]] and [[Lamberto Leoni]]. The results achieved were unremarkable apart from [[Lamberto Leoni]]'s third place in the [[Pau Grand Prix|Pau]] street race.

The '''Lola THL1''' was a [[Formula One]] racing car designed by [[Neil Oatley]] and [[John Baldwin (engineer)|John Baldwin]] for [[Haas Lola|Team Haas (USA) Ltd.]] during four of the last five races of the [[1985 Formula One season]]. The car used the {{Convert|750|bhp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}}, [[turbocharger|turbocharged]] [[Brian Hart Ltd.|Hart 415T]] [[Straight 4]] engine. The Haas Lola team only had one car for 1985 and it was driven by {{f1|1980}} World Champion [[Alan Jones (racing driver)|Alan Jones]], who was making a full-time comeback to Formula One at the age of 39.

==1985==
The THL1 maded its debut at the [[1985 Italian Grand Prix|Italian Grand Prix]] at [[Autodromo Nazionale Monza|Monza]], with Jones qualifying 25th, 9.859 seconds behind pole sitter [[Ayrton Senna]] ([[Lotus 97T|Lotus]]-[[Renault F1|Renault]]), but retiring after just 6 laps due to an overheating engine. The next race, the [[1985 Belgian Grand Prix|Belgian Grand Prix]], had been re-scheduled from June 2 so the team were not allowed to compete because they were not on the original entry list. Jones then qualified 18th for the [[1985 South African Grand Prix|South African Grand Prix]] which saw the French Renault and [[Equipe Ligier|Ligier]] teams boycott the race for political reasons, and the [[RAM Racing|RAM]] and [[Zakspeed]] teams not enter, but withdrew before the race due to illness (rumour had it that the Haas team had bowed to political pressure and withdrew, though Jones refutes this contending that he was indeed sick with the flu).

Jones showed the potential of the car in the final race of the season, the first ever [[Australian Grand Prix|Australian]] Formula One Grand Prix (the [[1985 Australian Grand Prix|1985 AGP]] was in fact the 50th running of the race, but it was the first time it was part of the [[FIA]] World Championship). The Australian qualified 19th for his home race but stalled the car at the start leaving him dead last. After getting a push start and being almost a quarter of a lap behind, Jones fought his way through the field and was up to 6th and into the points by lap 20 before being forced to retire with electrical trouble.

==1986==
The car was to be replaced for the start of the {{f1|1986}} season but the new [[Lola THL2]] was delayed meaning that the THL1 was pressed into service for the first three races of the season, its last race being the [[1986 San Marino Grand Prix|San Marino Grand Prix]]. Joining the [[Australian]] ex-World Champion in a second car was ex-[[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]] and [[Renault F1|Renault]] driver, [[Frenchman]] [[Patrick Tambay]]. The car would still use the turbocharged Hart engine, but when the THL2 appeared in [[1986 San Marino Grand Prix|San Marino]] for Jones to drive, it was powered by the new, {{Convert|900|bhp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]] [[Cosworth#Other Formula One engines|TEC]] [[V6 engine|V6]] turbo designed by [[Keith Duckworth]], the designer of the highly successful [[Cosworth DFV]] engine. Neither Jones or Tambay would score a point with the Lola Hart THL1. Despite Jones praising the new car and its engine, the team had finally got some speed out of the THL1 with Tambay qualifying 11th, some 2.226 faster and 12 places better than Jones in the THL2.

Interestingly the car was called a Lola but its only connection to the famous [[Lola Cars]] was because of car owner [[Carl Haas]]'s previous close association with Lola founder [[Eric Broadley]], who was also named as chief engineer for the team in 1985. The THL1 was actually designed by Haas-owned design and construction company known as FORCE (a member of Neil Oatley's design team was an up-and-coming [[Ross Brawn]]). Lola however earned the team's points towards the Constructors Championships as the team's designated constructor.

During a 2012 interview series with Formula One legends, Alan Jones described the underpowered Hart 415T engine as like "sending a man to do a boys job", adding that it was an old [[Formula 2]] engine that someone had thrown a turbo on and said "lets go and do Formula One". Up against the financial and technical resources of Ferrari, Renault, [[Honda F1|Honda]], [[BMW in Formula One|BMW]] and [[Techniques d'Avant Garde|TAG]]-[[Porsche in Formula One|Porsche]], results were few and far between for those using [[Brian Hart]]'s engines. The THL1 was the last car to use the turbocharged Hart engine in Formula One.

The '''Lola THL2''' was a [[Formula One]] racing car designed by [[Neil Oatley]] for FORCE and was used by [[Haas Lola|Team Haas (USA) Ltd.]] during the [[1986 Formula One season]] (two of the FORCE aerodynamicists who worked on the car during its countless hours of [[Wind tunnel]] testing were a young Ross Brawn and Adrian Newey. The car debuted at the [[1986 San Marino Grand Prix]] and was driven by {{f1|1980}} [[List of Formula One World Drivers' Champions|World Drivers' Champion]] [[Alan Jones (racing driver)|Alan Jones]] from [[Australia]], and his new team mate [[Patrick Tambay]] of [[France]].

Jones, with 12 career wins in his first F1 career from 1975-81 (plus one race for [[Arrows Grand Prix International|Arrows]] in {{f1|1983}}), had been with the team since its debut at the [[1985 Italian Grand Prix]]. Tambay joined after two seasons driving for the factory [[Equipe Renault|Renault]] team, and a season and a half with [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]] before that. Tabmay had 3 Grand Prix wins to his credit, all for Ferrari in {{f1|1982}} and 1983.

The car was an evolution of the [[Lola THL1]] which used the [[Brian Hart Ltd.|Hart 415T]] [[Straight 4]] [[turbocharger|turbo]]. When the THL2 appeared at Imola it was powered by the new [[Ford]] [[Cosworth#Other Formula One engines|TEC]], 120° [[V6]] turbo which was rated at about {{Convert|900|bhp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}}. Although it was an improvement in power over the {{Convert|750|bhp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} Hart engine, the Ford unfortunately lagged behind other engines in F1 in 1986 such as the reported {{Convert|1300|bhp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} bhp that the [[team Lotus|Lotus]] Renault V6 turbo had and the {{Convert|1400|bhp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} of the turbocharged 4cyl [[BMW M12|BMW]] engine. This led to a frustrating season for both Jones and Tambay as the THL2 was generally regarded to be the best handling car of the season. Jones and Tambay were reported to have continually asked engine designer [[Keith Duckworth]] of [[Cosworth]] to build special qualifying engines with more power like Renault, BMW and [[Honda Racing F1|Honda]] were doing in order to be able to qualify the car further up the grid, but the requests were turned down. Duckworth, Ford and Cosworth all believed that their proven reliability record would hold them in good stead against their sometimes fragile opposition.

Jones only scored 4 points during the season and retired from F1 for good at season's end. Tambay only scored two points with 5th place in [[1986 Austrian Grand Prix|Austria]]. Tambay also departed F1 at season's end, as did the Lola Haas team following the withdrawal of their major sponsor [[Beatrice Foods]]. The THL2s best qualifying position was 6th by Tambay at the [[Hungaroring]] for the [[1986 Hungarian Grand Prix]] where the tight nature of the circuit meant a good handling car was more important than outright power.

Like its predecessor, the car was called a Lola but its only connection to the famous [[Lola Cars]] was because of car owner [[Carl Haas]]'s previous close association with Lola founder [[Eric Broadley]], who was also named as chief engineer for the team in 1985.

The '''Zakspeed 891''' was a [[Formula One]] car for the {{f1|1989}} season run by the [[Germany|German]] [[Zakspeed]] team. Its drivers were German [[Bernd Schneider (racing driver)|Bernd Schneider]] in his second year with the team and F1 rookie [[Aguri Suzuki]] from [[Japan]]. The car was powered by F1 newcomer [[Yamaha Motor Company|Yamaha]] who had produced the [[Yamaha Motor Company#Racing heritage|OX88]] [[V8 engine]] for exclusive use by Zakspeed in Formula One.

Due to neither Schneider nor his {{f1|1988}} team mate [[Piercarlo Ghinzani]] scoring any points in the [[Zakspeed 881|881]], the team was forced into [[Formula One racing#Pre-qualifying|pre-qualifying]] in order to be able to try to qualify for a race. While Schneider was able to qualify his car 25th for the [[1989 Brazilian Grand Prix]], it would prove to be a false hope with the German only able to pre-qualify and qualify once more, at the [[1989 Japanese Grand Prix]]. Suzuki never made it past pre-qualifying at any of the 16 rounds during the season.

Most of this was attributed to what was found to be a very underpowered Yamaha engine. Late in the season following another double failure to pre-qualify at the [[1989 Spanish Grand Prix|Spanish Grand Prix]], the Yamaha OX88 V8 was reported to be producing only {{Convert|560|bhp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}}.<ref>[http://www.statsf1.com/es/moteur-yamaha.aspx StatsF1 - Yamaha OX88]</ref> This compared badly to the base {{Convert|620|bhp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} of the customer [[Cosworth DFR|Ford Cosworth]] and [[Judd (engine)#CV|Judd]] V8s and the [[Lamborghini V12|Lamborghini]] [[V12 engine|V12]] being used by most of the other teams. It was also unfavorable in comparison to the {{Convert|650|bhp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} - {{Convert|700|bhp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} bhp of the top four engines, the [[V10 engine|V10's]] of [[Honda Racing F1|Honda]] ([[McLaren]]) and [[Renault F1|Renault]] ([[WilliamsF1|Williams]]), the [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]] [[V12 engine|V12]], and the [[Cosworth#Other Formula One engines|Ford]] V8 ([[Benetton Formula|Benetton]]). This made Schneider qualifying 21st for the following race in Japan all the more impressive.

The 891 was the last Formula One car to be produced by Zakspeed as the team pulled out of Grand Prix racing following the 1989 season. Yamaha also pulled out of Formula One at the end of the year, but would return with the [[Brabham]] team in {{f1|1991}}.

'''''Thrust1''''' was a [[United Kingdom|British]]-designed and built [[jet engine|jet]]-propelled car. The car was designed and built by its driver [[Richard Noble]], who later achieved the [[land speed record]] with his car ''[[Thrust2]]''.<ref name="Noble, Thrust, Thrust1" >{{cite book
  |title=Thrust
  |chapter=3: A Cathedral on Wheels
  |last=Noble  |first=Richard
  |authorlink=Richard Noble
  |year=1998
  |publisher=Transworld
  |isbn=1-85225-268-5
  |ref=Noble, Thrust
  |pages=33–45
}}</ref>

''Thrust1'' itself was never intended to be a contender for the record. Noble's plan was for three cars: ''Thrust1'' "to learn the ropes",<ref name="Noble, Thrust, three cars" >[[#Noble, Thrust|Noble, Thrust]], p.&nbsp;33</ref> a second demonstration car to raise interest and the essential large-scale sponsorship, then ''Thrust3'' for an attempt on the record.<ref name="Noble, Thrust, three cars" />

==Details==
The car was powered by a military-surplus [[Rolls-Royce Derwent]] engine, as the simplest jet engine available. The particular engine used was a Mk&nbsp;8 from a [[Gloster Meteor]]<ref group="notes" >Sourced from well-known surplus dealers, Portsmouth Marine Salvage</ref> of around 3,500 pounds thrust. The [[ladder chassis]] was also acquired as surplus, from Noble's employers [[GKN|GKN Sankey]]. The extremely tight project budget was initially funded by Noble selling his own car, a [[Triumph TR6]].<ref group="notes" >A chassis, incidentally, built in part of the same GKN Sankey plant</ref><ref name="Noble, Thrust, Thrust1" /> The direct costs of the project, estimated afterwards, were at around £1,500, including £1,100 for the TR6<ref name="Noble, Thrust, Thrust1 costs" >[[#Noble, Thrust|Noble, Thrust]], p.&nbsp;46</ref> Sponsorship was acquired from a variety of small agreements, including sponsorship-in-kind from the tool manufacturer [[Black & Decker]]. Construction began in the garage of Noble's flat in [[Thames Ditton]]. By 1975, the car was completed in a [[lock-up garage]] at [[Turnham Green]].<ref name="Noble, Thrust, Thrust1" />

The first test run was at [[RAF St Athan]] in South Wales. This was little more than a shakedown at low power, and no more than 80&nbsp;mph. A demonstration run for filming was also made around the circuit at [[Brands Hatch]]. Runs were also conducted at [[RNAY Wroughton]] near Swindon. By 1977 the team were ready for a high-speed run, planned for the long 10,000&nbsp;foot runway of [[RAF Fairford]]<ref name="Noble, Thrust, Thrust1" />

The first high-speed run was planned for 7 March 1977, the day after Noble's thirty-first birthday.<ref name="Noble, Thrust, Thrust1" /> A successful first run was made from a standing start at idle thrust and gradual acceleration, reaching an estimated top speed of 180&nbsp;mph. The second run was planned to be a drag start, with thrust built up against the brakes and then released. At around 140&nbsp;mph though, a rear-wheel bearing seized<ref group="notes" >The rear axle was from a normal production road car, including its differential casing and drum brakes.</ref> and the car went sideways, then rolled. The triple roll was mostly airborne and the car landed on its side, with relatively little damage. Noble was unhurt. The Derwent engine, and its protruding combustion chambers, took much of the damage. The jetpipe broke loose and at least one combustion chamber was crumpled.<ref name="Noble, Thrust, Thrust1" />

The car never ran again, and the wreckage was sold to a scrap dealer for £175, after parts had been removed to ensure that it ''could'' never be run again.<ref name="Noble, Thrust, Thrust1 costs" /> Despite the crash, Noble was not disheartened and saw this as the conclusion of the first step of his original plan.<ref name="Noble, Thrust, three cars" />

==Successor==

By October of the same year, an engine had already been acquired for the next project, ''[[Thrust2]]'' and this [[Rolls-Royce Avon]] was displayed at the London [[Motorfair]] to raise interest and sponsorship.<ref name="Noble, Thrust, Thrust2" >[[#Noble, Thrust|Noble, Thrust]], p.&nbsp;51</ref>

The '''IKCO Samand Soren''' is a large family car manufactured by [[Iran Khodro]] (IKCO). It is a [[facelift (automotive)|facelift]] version of the IKCO [[Samand]], first released in early 2007.<ref>[http://www.farsnews.com/printable.php?nn=8511180751 FarsNews] ('''Persian''')</ref> It comes with a driver airbag, pretensioner seat-belts, headlight height adjuster, and active antenna. It is named after [[Surena]], an ancient Parthian [[spahbed]] (general).

==Soren ELX==

[[File:Soren in Kermanshah.jpg|thumb|Soren in Kermanshah|270px]]
The Samand Soren ELX is a modified version of the Samand Soren, released in 2008. It has a number of new safety options including ESP (as an option) and a front passenger airbag. It also has a new interior design, including a new dashboard and instrument cluster. Its electrical systems are fully digitized.

There are three available engines for the Samand Soren ELX:

*[[IKCO EF Engines#EF7|EF7]]
*[[IKCO EF Engines#EF7 turbocharged|EF7TC]]
*[[PSA TU engine#TU5|Peugeot TU5JP4]]

The '''Toleman TG185''' was a [[Formula One]] racing car designed by [[Rory Byrne]] and was used by [[Toleman|Toleman Motorsport]] during the majority [[1985 Formula One season]]. The car was powered by the {{Convert|800|bhp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} [[Brian Hart Ltd.|Hart 415T]] [[Straight 4]] [[turbocharger|turbocharged]] engine. The car was late in arriving for the 1985 season for no other reason than a lack of tyres. In {{f1|1984}} Toleman started the season using tyres supplied by [[Italy|Italian]] company [[Pirelli]]. Part way through the season though the team pulled out of their tyre contract with Pirelli and started using the [[France|French]] [[Michelin]]s instead. However, when Michelin pulled out of F1 at the end of 1984, the team were unable to come to an agreement to use [[Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company|Goodyear]] rubber. They were also unable to get a deal with Pirelli who were reluctant to supply tyres for the team. It was only after team sponsor [[Benetton Group|Benetton]] bought [[Spirit Racing]] and transferred their Pirelli contract to Toleman that the team were able to run in 1985.

The car was fundamentally unchanged from the [[Toleman TG184|TG184]] apart from a revised suspension to deal with running different rubber and revised rear bodywork. The car was initially driven by former [[Brabham]] driver [[Teo Fabi]] of Italy. He was joined in the team from the 10th race ([[1985 Austrian Grand Prix|Austria]]) by fellow Italian [[Piercarlo Ghinzani]]. Fabi gave the Toleman Team its first and only pole position when he qualified on pole for the [[1985 German Grand Prix|German Grand Prix]] held at the new [[Nürburgring]] circuit. Fabi set his time in the Friday qualifying session and as it rained on the Saturday no one else could beat his time. Unfortunately he got a bad start in the race due to a slipping clutch and was only 10th going into the first corner. The clutch would be the cause of the car's retirement from the race on lap 29.

The TG185 was the last F1 car for Toleman Group Motorsport. From the {{f1|1986}} season the team was bought out by main sponsor Benetton and renamed [[Benetton Formula|Benetton Formula Ltd.]] Fabi's pole in Germany was the highlight of the year. After finishing 1984 in 7th place in the Constructors' Championship with 16 points (including 3 podiums by rookie driver [[Ayrton Senna]]), the team failed to score a point in 1985. In fact, the TG185 proved almost totally unreliable with only 2 finishes all season when Fabi finished 14th in [[1985 French Grand Prix|France]] and 12th in [[1985 Italian Grand Prix|Italy]], while Ghinzani failed to finish a race.

Following the acquisition of Toleman the planned {{f1|1986}} car, dubbed the "TG186", was simply renamed the [[Benetton B186]]. That car, powered by the {{Convert|1400|bhp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} [[BMW M12]] engine went on to became the team's first ever Grand Prix winner when [[Gerhard Berger]] drove it to victory at the [[1986 Mexican Grand Prix]].

The '''Benetton B187''' was a [[Formula One]] racing car designed by [[Rory Byrne]] and raced by [[Benetton Formula|Benetton]] team in the [[1987 Formula One season]]. The B187 replaced the [[Benetton B186|B186]] used in the {{f1|1986}} season.

In 1987 Benetton effectively became the [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]] works team in F1 as they had exclusive use of the [[turbocharger|turbocharged]] [[Ford]] [[Cosworth#Other Formula One engines|TEC]] [[V6 engine]] for 1987, rated at approximately {{Convert|900|bhp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}}. Driven by [[Belgium|Belgian]] [[Thierry Boutsen]] and [[Italy|Italian]] [[Teo Fabi]], the team and the B187 got off to a good start with Boutsen finishing 5th at the season opening [[1987 Brazilian Grand Prix|Brazilian Grand Prix]] and by mid-season both Fabi and Boutsen were regularly challenging the top 4 teams of [[McLaren]], [[WilliamsF1|Williams]], [[Team Lotus|Lotus]] and [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]] for podium finishes. Boutsen led the [[1987 Mexican Grand Prix|Mexican Grand Prix]] (the race the team had won in [[1986 Mexican Grand Prix|1986]]) before being forced to retire.

Boutsen finished the season in 8th place with 16 points while Fabi, in his last year in F1, was 9th with 12 points scored. Overall with the B187, Benetton finished 5th in the constructors championship with 28 points. For Benetton this was a 9 point and 1 place improvement on the 1986 season, although unlike 1986, the team did not win a race in 1987.

The B187 was the last of the turbo cars produced by Benetton (dating back to when [[Toleman]] produced its first car, the TG181 in {{f1|1981}}) and was replaced in {{f1|1988}} by the [[Naturally aspirated engine|Naturally aspirated]], [[Cosworth DFR|Ford DFR]], [[V8 engine|V8]] powered [[Benetton B188|B188]]. The B188 would the first car constructed by the team, either as Toleman or Benetton, that would not be powered by a turbocharged engine.

The B187 was driven by [[Jackie Stewart]] in 1989 as part of a show where he drove a number of race cars, including several Formula One machines, and declared it to be one of the better cars he drove. The B187 was the last F1 car driven by Teo Fabi, the Italian being pushed out of the team for 1988 with the signing of fellow Italian [[Alessandro Nannini]]. With no offers for a drive in 1988, Fabi's last race for the team was the [[1987 Australian Grand Prix|Australian Grand Prix]]. It was at this race that a disgruntled Fabi deliberately held up Boutsen from lapping him for several laps despite repeated pit board signs and radio messages to let his team mate past.

The '''March 871''' was a [[Formula One]] [[racing car]] designed by the [[March Engineering|March Racing Team]] and driven in the [[1987 Formula One season]]. The car was powered by a [[Cosworth DFZ]] V8 engine, and was driven by the [[1986 International Formula 3000 season|1986 International Formula 3000]] champion, Italian [[Ivan Capelli]].

The team was sponsored by Japanese real estate company [[Leyton House]].

The 871 chassis was not ready for the first race in [[1987 Brazilian Grand Prix|Brazil]]. So the team used an F3000/F1 hybrid called the 87P. The 871 was ready for the second race in [[1987 San Marino Grand Prix|San Marino]].

The best result and the only points were achieved with a 6th place at the [[1987 Monaco Grand Prix]]. However Capelli and the March 871 did finish 4th in the Colin Chapman Trophy for constructors of cars equipped with naturally aspirated engines.

'''Delahaye 135''' was an automobile manufactured by [[Delahaye]]. Designed by young engineer Jean François, it was produced from 1935 until 1954 in many different [[Car body style|body styles]]. A sporting tourer, it was also popular for racing.<ref name="1930s Cars">{{cite book | title = A-Z of Cars of the 1930s | last = Sedgwick | first = Michael | last2 = Gillies | first2 = Mark | publisher = Bay View Books | year = 1989 | pages = 66–67 | location = Bideford, Devon, UK | isbn = 1-870979-38-9 }}</ref>

==History==
The Delahaye 135, also known as "''Coupe des Alpes''" after its success in the [[Alpine Rally]], was first presented in 1935 and signified Delahaye's decision to build sportier cars than before. The 3.2-litre [[overhead valve]] straight-six with four-bearing [[crankshaft]] was derived from one of Delahaye's truck engines and was also used in the more sedate, longer wheelbase ({{convert|3160|mm|in|0|abbr=on|disp=or}}) Delahaye '''138'''. Power was {{convert|95|hp|kW|abbr=on}} in twin carburetor form,<ref name="Rousseau">{{Cite book | title = Guide de l'Automobile Française | last = Rousseau | first = Jacques | last2 = Caron | first2 = Jean-Paul | publisher = Solar | year = 1988 | chapter = 128 | location = Paris | isbn = 2-263-01105-6 }}</ref> but {{convert|110|hp|kW|abbr=on}} were available in a version with three downdraught [[Solex#Carburetors|Solex]] carbs,<ref name="1930s Cars"/> offering a {{convert|148|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} top speed. The 138 had a single carburetor and {{convert|76|hp|kW|abbr=on}}, and was available in a sportier {{convert|90|hp|kW|abbr=on}} iteration.<ref>Rousseau & Caron, "127".</ref>

The 135 featured independent, [[leaf-sprung]] front suspension, a [[Live axle|live rear axle]], and cable operated [[Bendix Corporation|Bendix]] brakes. 17-inch spoked wheels were also standard. Transmission was either a partially [[Synchromesh|synchronized]] four-speed manual or four-speed [[Preselector gearbox|Cotal pre-selector]] [[Transmission (mechanics)|transmission]].<ref>Hull, Peter. "Delahaye: Famous on Road and Race Track", in Ward, Ian, executive editor. ''World of Automobiles'' (London: Orbis, 1974), Volume 5, p.523.</ref>

Competition 135s set the all-time record at the [[Ulster Tourist Trophy]] and placed second and third in the ''[[Mille Miglia]]'' in 1936,<ref>Hull, p.522.</ref> and the [[1938 24 Hours of Le Mans]].<ref>Hull, p.524.</ref>

The list of independent body suppliers offering to clothe the 135 chassis is the list of France's top [[Coachbuilding|coachbuilder]]s of the time, including [[Figoni & Falaschi]], [[Letourneur et Marchand]], Guilloré, [[Marcel Pourtout]], Frères Dubois, [[Saoutchik|J Saoutchik]], [[Franay]], Antem and [[Henri Chapron]].<ref name=Automobilia1948>{{cite journal| authorlink = René Bellu  | title =Automobilia| journal = Toutes les voitures françaises 1948 (salon Paris oct 1947)| volume = Nr. 7| pages = Pages 26–35|year = 1998|isbn = |publisher=Histoire & collections|location=Paris }}</ref>

Production of the 3.2-litre version ended with the [[German occupation of France during World War II|German occupation]] in 1940 and was not taken up again after the end of hostilities.

===135M===
[[File:1949 Delahaye type 148 L Berline front.jpg|thumb|left|1949 '''148L''' with four-door ''berline'' bodywork by [[Letourneur et Marchand]]]]
[[File:135dub7.jpg|thumb|The special version ''Gascogne'' (1948).]]

A larger-[[Engine displacement|displacement]] (3,557&nbsp;cc) 135M was introduced in 1936. Largely the same as the regular 135, the new engine offered 90, 105, or 115&nbsp;hp with either one, two, or three carburetors.<!-->Peter Hull, in"Delahaye: Famous on Road and Race Track", in Ward, Ian, executive editor. ''World of Automobiles'' (London: Orbis, 1974), Volume 5, p.523, says up to 130hp.--> As with the 135/138, a less sporty, longer wheelbase version was also built, called the "148". The 148 had a 3,150&nbsp;mm wheelbase, or 3,350&nbsp;mm in a seven-seater version. On the two shorter wheelbases, a [[Delahaye 134|134]]N was also available, with a 2,150&nbsp;cc four-cylinder version of the 3.2-litre six from the 135. Along with a brief return of the 134, production of 148, 135M, and 135MS models was resumed after the end of the war. The 135 and 148 were then joined by the larger engined [[Delahaye 175|175, 178, and 180 derivatives]]. The 135M continued to be available alongside the newer [[Delahaye 235|235]] until the demise of Delahaye in 1954.

====168====
Presented in December 1938 and built until the outbreak of war in 1940, the Type 168 used the 148L's chassis and engine (engine code 148N) in [[:fr:Renault Viva Grand Sport|Renault Viva Grand Sport]] bodywork. Wheelbase remained 315&nbsp;cm while the use of [[artillery wheel]]s rather than spoked items meant minor differences in track. This curious hybrid was the result of an effort by Renault to steal in on Delahaye's lucrative near monopoly on fire vehicles: after a complaint by Delahaye, Renault relinquished contracts it had gained, but in return Delahaye had to agree to purchase a number of Viva Grand Sport bodyshells. In an effort to limit the market of this [[Brood parasite|cuckoo's egg]], thus limiting the number of bodyshells it had to purchase from Renault, Delahaye chose to equip it with the unpopular [[Preselector gearbox#Wilson gearbox|Wilson preselector]] (even though the marketing material referred to the Cotal version). This succeeded very well, and with the war putting a stop to car production, no more than thirty were supposedly built. Strong, wide, and fast, like their Viva Grand Sport half sisters, the 168s proved popular with the army. Many were equipped to run on [[Wood gas generator|''gazogène'']] during the war and very few (if any) remain.<ref>{{Cite journal | title = Un tiroir de l'inconnu: La Delahaye 168 | trans_title = A drawer of the unknown: The Delahaye 168 | last = Jolly | first = François | language = French | editor-last = Pozzoli | editor-first = Serge | date = July 1978 | journal = Le Fanatique de l'Automobile | issue = 118 | page = 18 | publisher = Editions Larivière | location = Paris | issn = 0336-9072 }}</ref>

===135MS===
[[File:Delahaye 135MS Competition.JPG|thumb|Short wheelbase 135MS (1937)]]

An even sportier version, the 135MS, soon followed; 120–145&nbsp;hp were available, with competition versions offering over 160&nbsp;hp.<ref name="1930s Cars"/> The 135MS was the version most commonly seen in competition, and continued to be available until 1954, when new owners [[Hotchkiss et Cie|Hotchkiss]] finally called a halt. The MS had the 2.95&nbsp;m wheelbase, but competition models sat on a shortened 2.70&nbsp;m chassis.

The [[Delahaye 235|type 235]], a rebodied 135MS with ponton-style design by [[Philippe Charbonneaux]], appeared in 1951.

==Competition==
The 135 was successful as racing car during the late 1930s, winning the [[Monte Carlo rally]] 1937 and [[24 Hours of Le Mans]] in 1938.<ref>{{cite web|author=the Auto Editors of Consumer Guide |url=http://auto.howstuffworks.com/1936-delahaye-135-competition-coupe.htm |title=Howstuffworks: 1936 Delahaye 135 Competition Coupé |publisher=Auto.howstuffworks.com |date=2007-10-29 |accessdate=2011-09-25}}</ref> The Le Mans victory, with Chaboud and Trémoulet at the wheel, was decisive, with two more Delahayes coming in second and fourth. A regular 135 came seventh at the 1935 Le Mans, and in 1937 135MS came in second and third. Appearing again in 1939, two 135MS made it to sixth and eighth place, and again after the war the now venerable 135MS finished in 5th, 9th, and 10th.<ref name="Rousseau"/>

The '''Tyrrell DG016''' was a [[Formula One]] racing car designed by [[Maurice Philippe]] and [[Brian Lisles]]. It was built and raced by [[Tyrrell Racing]] in the [[1987 Formula One season]], using a customer [[Cosworth DFZ]] engine. The "DG" in the car's name was a reference to the team's major sponsor, [[Data General]].

The DG016 made its debut at the opening race of the [[1987 Formula One season]] and would be part of two different championships. For 1987 only there would be the [[Colin Chapman]] Trophy (for constructors of cars equipped with [[naturally aspirated engines]]). In this championship the Tyrrell DG016 was a major success finishing 1st by over 100 points from the [[Larrousse]]-Calmels Team (helped by Tyrrell being the only two car 'atmo' team to run both cars for the entire season). Drivers [[Jonathan Palmer]] and [[Philippe Streiff]] would have finished on the naturally aspirated podium at all 16 rounds of the season.

The car was also successful in the full Constructors' Championship with 6th place, including points finishes for Palmer in [[1987 Monaco Grand Prix|Monaco]] and [[1987 Australian Grand Prix|Australia]], for Streiff in [[1987 French Grand Prix|France]], and remarkably for both drivers in [[1987 German Grand Prix|Germany]] at the fast [[Hockenheimring]] circuit whose long straights did not suit the 'atmo' cars (largely thanks to 13 of the 18 turbo runners failing to finish due to either engine or turbo failure). The result in Germany was even more remarkable considering that Streiff and Palmer qualified 22nd and 23rd respectively, with Streiff 10.912 seconds slower than the pole time set by [[Nigel Mansell]] in his [[Williams FW11|Williams]]-[[Honda F1|Honda]] turbo, while the fastest race lap for the DG016, again set by Streiff, was 8.512 seconds slower than Mansell's fastest lap of the race. Despite being significantly slower than the turbos, both Tyrrells only finished one lap behind race winner and 1987 World Champion [[Nelson Piquet]] in his Williams-Honda.

These results helped place Tyrrell above such turbo powered teams as [[Arrows Grand Prix International|Arrows]] (7th) and [[Brabham]] (8th) in the open Constructors' Championship.

The DG016 was replaced for the [[1988 Formula One season]] by the equally unsuccessful [[Tyrrell 017]].

The '''Zakspeed 881''' was a [[Formula One]] car designed by Chris Murphy and Heinz Zollner and raced by [[Zakspeed]] in the [[1988 Formula One season]]. The car was the last to be powered by the team's own 1.5 litre [[straight 4]] [[turbo]] engine, the '''1500/4'''. The car was driven by veteran [[Piercarlo Ghinzani]] and [[West Germany|West German]] F1 rookie [[Bernd Schneider (racing driver)|Bernd Schneider]].

The 881 was a development of the team's {{f1|1987}} car, the [[Zakspeed 871|871]], and was a largely unsuccessful car in the last year for turbos in Formula One. Both Ghinzani and Schneider, who replaced 1987 drivers [[Martin Brundle]] and [[Christian Danner]], struggled all season to qualify the car even against the slower [[Naturally aspirated engine|atmospheric]] cars. A glaring example of this was at [[Silverstone Circuit|Silverstone]] for the [[1988 British Grand Prix|British Grand Prix]]. At the fastest circuit on the calendar that should have suited the turbo powered cars, both Ghinzani and Schneider failed to qualify, the Zakspeeds being the only turbo cars not to do so. The 881 was also unreliable, often blowing either the engine or the turbo many times over a race weekend. Neither Zakspeed driver scored a point in 1988, which meant the team was forced to pre-qualify in {{f1|1989}}.

The 881 was the last F1 car in which Zakspeed used their own engines which were rated at about {{Convert|640|bhp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} for the season. While this made the engine one of the most powerful in the field, being only about 10 bhp shy of both the [[Honda F1|Honda]] and [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]] [[V6 engine]]s, and around the same as the other straight 4 turbo in the field, the [[BMW M12|Megatrons]] used by [[Arrows Grand Prix International|Arrows]], that is where the similarities ended. Honda powered [[McLaren]] to 15 wins and 15 pole positions during the season, with the other win and pole going to Ferrari. Ghinzani failed to qualify on seven occasions while Schneider failed to qualify ten times.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gurneyflap.com/zakspeedengine.html |title=Zakspeed F1 Engines at |publisher=Gurneyflap.com |accessdate=2012-01-07}}</ref> Something that did not help the team's cause was the weight of the car. The 881 weighed in at {{convert|560|kg|lb||abbr=on}}, this was around {{convert|20|kg|lb||abbr=on}} heavier than the [[McLaren MP4/4]], [[Ferrari F1/87|Ferrari F1/87/88C]] and the Honda powered [[Lotus 100T]].

Bernd Schneider recorded the team's best finish for the year when he finished 12th in his and the team's home race in [[1988 German Grand Prix|Germany]] at [[Hockenheimring|Hockenheim]]. The German rookie had to wait until Round 4 in [[1988 Mexican Grand Prix|Mexico]] to qualify for his first race. There at the [[Autodromo Hermanos Rodriguez]] in the high altitude of [[Mexico City]] where the thinner air gave the turbos a massive power advantage over their atmospheric rivals (the 'atmos' lost a reported 25% of their power at altitude while the turbos lost around 5%), Schneider qualified in an encouraging 15th place and ran well early on the edge of the top 10 until retiring with engine failure on lap 16.

The 881's replacement, the [[Zakspeed 891]], would be powered by a [[Yamaha Motor Company#Racing heritage|Yamaha]] [[V8 engine]].

The '''Zakspeed 871''' was a [[Formula One]] car designed by Chris Murphy and Heinz Zollner and raced by [[Zakspeed]] in the [[1987 Formula One season]]. The car was powered by the team's own 1.5 litre, 1500/4 [[straight 4]] [[turbo]] engine, which was rated at about {{Convert|920|bhp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} for the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gurneyflap.com/zakspeedengine.html |title=Zakspeed F1 Engines at |publisher=Gurneyflap.com |accessdate=2012-01-07}}</ref> [[Martin Brundle]] had moved after 3 years at [[Tyrrell Racing|Tyrrell]] to be Zakspeed's lead driver, in a virtual driver swap with [[Jonathan Palmer]], who had left Zakspeed after two seasons to drive for Tyrrell. Brundle was joined by former [[1985 International Formula 3000 season|Formula 3000]] champion [[Christian Danner]], who had moved from [[Arrows Grand Prix International|Arrows]].

After using the [[Zakspeed 861|861]] for the first race in [[1987 Brazilian Grand Prix|Brazil]], the 871 made its debut in Brundle's hands at the [[1987 San Marino Grand Prix|San Marino Grand Prix]] where he qualified 15th and scored 2 points for finishing 5th. This happened to be the only time that Zakspeed would ever score a point during their time in Formula One.

The 871 was replaced for the {{f1|1988}} season by the team's last ever turbo car, the [[Zakspeed 881]] which would be again powered by the team's own turbocharged engine.

The team's main sponsor was German tobacco company [[West (cigarette)|West]].

'''Citroën Survolt''' is a concept [[electric car|electric]] [[race car|racing car]] produced by [[Citroën]] and presented at the 2010 [[Geneva Motor Show]].

==Overview==
The Survolt is a compact-sized racing car based on the concept car [[Citroën Revolte]] presented at the 2009 [[Frankfurt Motor Show]]. Because the car runs on batteries, it is classed as a [[Zero-emissions vehicle]].

==Design==
The Survolt is 3.85 meters (12.63&nbsp;feet) long, 1.87 meters (6.14&nbsp;feet) wide and 1.20 meters (3.94&nbsp;feet) high and features a design with the front dominated by the vehicle's badge located above the large oval-shaped grille.

The car has horizontal [[LED light|LED]] [[headlamp]]s which have lower power consumption than traditional filament bulbs — important in a battery-operated vehicle.

At the back, the Survolt maintains the light cluster design used on the REVOLTe, and has a [[Spoiler (automotive)|spoiler]] to increase rear downforce.

An Art Car based on the Survolt has been designed with the collaboration of  [[Françoise Nielly]] in 2011.

==Engine and drivetrain==
The Survolt is powered by a pair of [[electric motor]]s with a combined power output of {{convert|300|bhp|abbr=on}}.  Its top speed is {{convert|260|km/h|abbr=on}}, and it can accelerate from 0–{{convert|100|km/h|abbr=on}} in less than 5 seconds. Citroën claims that the batteries provide a range of {{convert|200|km|mi|abbr=on}}.{{cn|date=February 2015}}

==Motorsports==
The Citroën Survolt made its first appearance on a [[racetrack]] at [[Le Mans]] on 12 July 2010. [[Vanina Ickx]] was the first driver to get behind the wheel of the Survolt.

Although it has not been confirmed that the Survolt will ever be produced, there are rumors that Citroën wants to create a limited-production of a [[compact car|compact]]-sized concept based on this car, and start a [[one-make racing]] series. The Citroën Survolt will be produced in 2018 as a production car.{{Citation needed|date=February 2013}}

==Media appearances==
The Citroën Survolt makes an appearance in ''[[Asphalt 6: Adrenaline]]'', ''[[Asphalt 8: Airborne]]'' and ''GT Racing 2'', all of which are mobile racing games by [[Gameloft]]. The Survolt is also on a mobile, or Facebook, racing game called Racing Rivals by [[Glu Mobile]]. It is also available on [[Driveclub]] for [[PlayStation 4]] as a free [[downloadable content]].

The British automobile test driving show Top Gear has driven the car around their famous test track and has given it high marks except for the fact that it is exceptionally hard to climb in and out of.<ref name="Top Gear">http://www.topgear.com/uk/car-news/tg-drives-the-citroen-survolt</ref>

The '''Tyrrell 015''' was a [[Formula One]] car designed for [[Tyrrell Racing]] by [[Maurice Philippe]] for use in the {{f1|1986}} season. The cars were powered by the turbocharged [[Renault F1|Renault EF15]] [[V6 engine]] which was rated at {{Convert|850|bhp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} in race trim. The 015 ran on [[Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company|Goodyear]] tyres and were driven by [[Martin Brundle]] in his third season with the team, and [[Philippe Streiff]] who joined from [[Equipe Ligier|Ligier]].

The 015 was a development of the team's first ever turbo car, the [[Tyrrell 014]] which had first run the Renault turbo in Brundle's hands at the [[1985 French Grand Prix]]. As the 015 was still unfinished at the start of the season, the team ran the 014 for the first three races of the season. The new car was finally ready for [[1986 Monaco Grand Prix|Monaco]] and proved to be somewhat reliable, if not the fastest car on the grid. Of the three teams which used versions of the turbocharged Renault V6 during the season, Tyrrell were usually slower than both Ligier and [[Team Lotus|Lotus]]. This was usually explained by Lotus having a works contract to run the latest engines (as well as having the undisputed fastest driver in Grand Prix racing, Brundle's old [[British Formula 3 Championship|British F3]] rival [[Ayrton Senna]]), while the French Ligier team had been using the French engines since {{f1|1984}}. Tyrrell on the other hand, had a failed relationship with Renault during the early 1970s which prompted the factory to eventually form its own team in {{f1|1977}}, only had a contract to run customer engines which were usually the oldest, least powerful and economical of those on offer.

The car's best result wasn't achieved until the final race of the season in [[1986 Australian Grand Prix|Australia]] when Brundle finished in 4th place despite running out of fuel as he crossed the line. He had actually inherited 4th from his team mate when Streiff ran out of fuel on the previous lap. Streiff was still classified in 5th place. Brundle also scored the team's best starting position for the year when he qualified 10th for the car's debut at Monaco.

The 015 made headlines for the wrong reasons at the [[1986 French Grand Prix|French Grand Prix]] when Streiff's car caught fire in front of the pits on lap 43. Despite the car being on fire directly beyond the pit wall the marshals fire truck took nearly a minute to get to it which gave enough time for the car to be burnt beyond repair.

This was the last turbo powered car run by Tyrrell in Formula One. After losing their Renault engines when the factory pulled out of Formula One altogether at the end of 1986, the team reverted to using [[Cosworth]] power when they ran the 3.0 litre [[Cosworth DFZ|Ford Cosworth DFZ]] [[V8 engine]] in their {{f1|1987}} car, the [[Tyrrell DG016|DG016]].

'''Egy-Tech Engineering''' ({{lang|ar|ايجى تك}}) is a [[car manufacturer]] located in [[Cairo]], [[Egypt]]. The company is specialized in manufacturing [[three wheeler|three-wheeled vehicles]] in the class of [[city car]]s and [[autorikshaw]]s. The company was founded in 1997.

Since January 2010, the company offers the two car models [[Egy-Tech Maestro]] and [[Egy-Tech Micro]]. Both models are available with the same range of engines. The smallest engine has a capacity of 150 cc (8.7 [[Kilowatt|kW]], 11.7 [[horsepower|hp]]), the middle one is represented by the 175 cc version with a power of 9.8&nbsp;kW (13.1&nbsp;hp). The third engine offered is a 200 cc version which has a power of 10.2&nbsp;kW (13.7&nbsp;hp), with the largest being currently a 250 cc version with a power of 11.4&nbsp;kW (15.3&nbsp;hp). The engines are manufactured by the [[Arab Industrialization Authority]]. The maximum speed reached by the vehicles is 60&nbsp;km/h. The prices range from [[Egyptian pound|EGP]] 17,450 to EGP 17,490. Egy-Tech is the first car manufacturer to use only car components made in Egypt.

The '''Ligier JS29''' was a [[Formula One]] car designed by [[Michel Tétu]] and [[Michel Beaujon]] for the [[Equipe Ligier|Ligier]] team for use in the {{f1|1987}} season. It was originally developed for use with an Alfa Romeo turbo power plant but prior to the start of the season, Ligier lost the use of the engine. The car had to be re-designed around a [[BMW M12|Megatron]] [[Straight 4]] [[Turbocharger|turbo]] engine. Redesignated the '''JS29B''', it scored a single point during the season when driver [[Rene Arnoux]] finished 6th in the [[1987 Belgian Grand Prix|Belgian Grand Prix]]. Later in the season, the car was further refined to a '''JS29C''' specification.

==Development==
The JS29 was originally to be powered by a brand new turbocharged [[Alfa Romeo in Formula One#Time after constructor years|Alfa-Romeo 415T]] 4-cylinder engine. However, during pre-season testing lead driver [[René Arnoux]] compared the engine to used food which gave Alfa's parent company [[Fiat]] the excuse they had been looking for to pull the plug on the project. It was reported at the time that Fiat did not want Alfa Romeo involved in Formula One as a competitor to [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]] who at that stage they part-owned.

As a result of losing their engine supply so close to the start of the season, Ligier had to come up with an engine in order to compete. The team managed to get a supply of [[BMW M12|Megatron]] [[Straight 4]] [[Turbocharger|turbo]] engines for the season (the Megatron engine was the old [[BMW M12]] engine formerly used by such teams as [[Brabham]]. They had been acquired from [[BMW]] by [[Arrows Grand Prix International|Arrows]] major sponsor, American insurance company [[USF&G]], and were re-branded ''Megatron'' for 1987 and {{f1|1988}}). The updated car with the Megatron engine was now designated the '''JS29B'''. Arnoux was retained for the season and he was joined by [[Italian people|Italian]] veteran [[Piercarlo Ghinzani]].

The JS29 should have made its debut at the [[1987 Brazilian Grand Prix]] using the Alfa Romeo 890T [[V8 engine|V8]] turbo until the 415T was ready. However, following Arnoux's unfavourable comments, and Fiat's withdrawal, this meant that the team had no engine with which to compete until the second race in [[1987 San Marino Grand Prix|San Marino]]. It was there that the JS29B with its Megatron engine would make its competition debut. The JS29B was updated following the [[1987 Detroit Grand Prix|Detroit Grand Prix]] to its final JS29C specifications. While the JS29 was originally designed for the 4-cylinder Alfa engine, it wasn't simply a case of slotting in the replacement Megatron 4-cylinder in its place. Major differences in the 'plumbing' of the two engines caused the team to have to redesign the car, including its rear suspension, as the Megatron was causing bad vibrations which was causing suspension failures.

As a result of the late start to the season due to their switch of engines, the Megatron powered Ligiers were never close to the pace of the [[Arrows A10]]-Megatrons of [[Derek Warwick]] and former Ligier driver [[Eddie Cheever]].

==Race history==
Arnoux placed his JS29B in 13th place in qualifying for the team's first race of the year at San Marino but failed to start the race following an accident in practice. Ghinzani was 19th and withdrew from the race with handling issues. At the next race, the [[1987 Belgian Grand Prix|Belgian Grand Prix]], both cars were classified with Arnoux in sixth place for the team's sole point of the year. Ghinzani was 7th although out of fuel and this proved to be his best finish of the year.

The JS29C was introduced at the team's [[1987 French Grand Prix|home grand prix]] in France with Arnoux qualifying in 13th place on the grid. As with Ghinzani, he failed to finish the race itself. The cars usually qualified in the lower half of the grid, with Arnoux outperforming Ghinzani.  The best qualifying achieved was Arnoux's 12th at the [[1987 German Grand Prix|German Grand Prix]].

The JS29C was Ligier's last turbo-powered car. It was replaced in the {{f1|1988}} season by the [[Judd (engine)#CV|Judd CV]] V8 powered [[Ligier JS31]].

The '''Ligier JS31''' was a [[Formula One]] car designed by [[Michel Tétu]] and [[Michel Beaujon]] for the [[Equipe Ligier|Ligier]] team for use in the [[1988 Formula One season]]. It was powered by the new, [[Naturally-aspirated engine|normally aspirated]], 3.5L [[Judd (engine)#CV|Judd CV]] [[V8 engine]] and, like the rest of the F1 grid in 1988, ran on [[Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company|Goodyear]] tyres. Drivers for the team were French veteran [[René Arnoux]] in his 3rd season driving for team boss [[Guy Ligier]], and Swede [[Stefan Johansson]] who had finished 5th in the World Championship with [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]] in {{f1|1986}} and 6th with [[McLaren]] in {{f1|1987}}.

The JS31 was the first non-[[Turbocharger|turbo]] car produced by Ligier since the [[Cosworth DFV]] powered [[Ligier JS21|JS21]] used in the {{f1|1983}} season, and it proved to be very uncompetitive despite the best efforts of the team and its experienced drivers. The car's major failure was a lack of downforce with Johansson in particular reporting several times during a frustrating season that he had to drive the car as if on a wet track because it had so little grip and this was reflected in the car's results. Johansson, a frequent podium visitor in the previous three seasons, failed to qualify six times and never finished above 9th while seven time grand prix winner Arnoux failed to qualify twice ([[1988 San Marino Grand Prix|San Marino]] and [[1988 French Grand Prix|France]]) and never finished a race higher than 10th. Neither driver qualified for the San Marino Grand Prix, the first time in team history that neither Ligier made the grid.

The French Grand Prix at [[Paul Ricard Circuit|Paul Ricard]] proved to be the lowest point of the season for the French team. On the eve of Arnoux's 40th birthday (celebrated the day after the race), neither Arnoux nor Johansson qualified for the team's home Grand Prix, something that did not please the team's owner [[Guy Ligier]], though as one team member pointed out thankfully he was not actually at Paul Ricard that weekend.

Ligier did not score a point during 1988, their worst season since [[1983 Formula One season|1983]], when they also failed to score. On several occasions both Johansson and Arnoux struggled to outqualify [[1987 International Formula 3000 season|1987 Formula 3000]] champion [[Stefano Modena]] and [[Sports car racing|sportscar]] driver, 33 year old [[Argentine]] [[Oscar Larrauri]] (an F1 rookie) in the equally uncompetitive [[EuroBrun]] (the EuroBrun team were F1 'rookies' in 1988, though Modena, who had made his debut with [[Brabham]] in 1987, was seen at that stage as a future star of the sport...if he could get a competitive drive). In an effort to optimise the weight distribution of the car, it was designed with an unusual and heavy arrangement of fuel tanks: there were two cells either side of the driver, another between the driver and the engine and a fourth between the engine and gearbox.<ref>Hodges (1990) p.134</ref>

Ligier only had both cars qualify for a race on 10 occasions in 1988. On 5 of those occasions both cars failed to finish.

The JS31 was replaced for 1989 by the [[Ligier JS33]].

The '''Tyrrell 011''' was a [[Formula One]] car designed by [[Maurice Philippe]] for the [[Tyrrell Racing|Tyrrell Racing Organisation]]. It made its debut in the hands of [[United States|American]] [[Eddie Cheever]] at the [[1981 German Grand Prix]] where he qualified 18th and finished the race in the points with 5th place. The car was powered by the [[Cosworth DFV]] [[V8 engine]] and initially ran on [[Avon Rubber|Avon]] tyres though the team later switched to [[Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company|Goodyear]] rubber.

The 011 raced in three seasons of Formula One ({{f1|1981}} - {{f1|1983}}) although its only full season was {{f1|1982}}. Drivers for Tyrrell in that time included Cheever, [[Michele Alboreto]], [[Brian Henton]], [[Slim Borgudd]] and [[Danny Sullivan]]. Tyrrell were able to win 2 races with the 011, both by Alboreto. The first win at the [[1982 Caesars Palace Grand Prix]] was also Alboreto's first and the last 011 victory was the [[1983 Detroit Grand Prix]]. This race was also the last of 155 Grand Prix wins for the Cosworth DFV engine which had made its F1 debut 16 years earlier in {{f1|1967}}.

The 1983 cars were green and black in colour and were sponsored by the Italian fashion brand [[Benetton Group|Benetton]].

The 011 was replaced two-thirds of the way through the 1983 season by the [[Tyrrell 012]].
